Life of Pi is a 3D adventure drama film adaptation of Yann Martel's novel of the same title that revolves around an Indian man named Piscine Molitor "Pi" Patel. He happens to be a novelist who lives in Canada that tells the story of how he survived a shipwreck at age 16 wherein his family dies and his experience of being stranded in lifeboat in the middle of the Pacific Ocean together with a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker. This leads him to adventure and a journey to self-discovery.

This movie is critical and commercial success. But I felt that it was a lot better on the technical level rather than the storytelling as the 3D special effects unfortunately somehow supersedes the emotional and insightful story of Pi. Too bad that the magnificent visual splendor of the film could take away the viewers attention to what the main character is all about especially in times of the most difficult moments of his life particularly in his struggle to survive and overcome the most painful ones when his family dies.

But nevertheless,one cannot deny that this remains a great film as it is a visual masterpiece from Ang Lee despite of the reasons mentioned above.
Excellent picture and sound in both 2D and 3D. especially when upscaled to 4K resolutions of all of our TVs.

The visuals in this story are quite stunning.  Even the opening credits are eye candy.  While the story isn't always fast-paced, there is always something to look at in beautiful 3D.  The ending of the story was quite surprising and a decent finish for the two hours I spent watching.

I haven't actually bought the 3D Blu-Ray, but I've seen this film in 3-D about 3-4 times in the theaters.  So this is more about addressing the one other review (at the time of posting) who also reviewed just the movie.

The other reviewer hated the movie and called it misleading.  People think the animals might all be cute and cuddly in this and that the film is for children; it's not.  In fact I would argue it's not suitable for anyone under 9yo in any way.  Mind you there's no profanity, nudity or sex; but it has animals acting in their best interest to survive.  And they are constantly in peril.  It's a movie for older teens and adults.  Despite the animal peril, it's not a depressing film in any way.

Having said that, there's a strong reason it was nominated for Best Picture, and Ang Lee actually won Best Director; it's probably the best movie of the few years.  And in this case, it's all about the telling of the story and not the actual story itself.  I can't tell you any more without giving spoilers, except to say if you are in a philosophical mood, it's definitely a movie you want to see.

And so having read the book through I have rewatched the movie. The book is the work of one man Yann Martel and tells of a sea journey involving a Bengal Tiger and one boy played by a nineteen-year-old that in the movie production took 40,000 people over a year to create. Hard to believe the entire ocean journey was shot in a gigantic water tank. First reaction is, I don't remember reading that in the book. Whether or not the story makes you believe in God the idea of someone surviving the two years ocean currents would take to carry one across the Pacific in essential solitary confinement is nearly impossible to believe. The tiger.... ?

The shots of the zoo in India are gorgeous. Many of the ocean shots are elegiac, the night shots of the stars in particular. Oceanic fluorescence and luminescence at night are a wonder to behold. The Pacific covers over one third of our planets surface and can produce storms with winds of nearly 200 mph and rogue waves capable of eating even the largest ships. Storms at sea make one feel hollow, infinitesimal, powerless. The vastness of this ocean on a calm day as seen from sea level in a lifeboat, mind numbing. All this the movie attempts to reproduce. Should be seen on a large screen but protect your hearing.

What Terence Malick tried very hard to accomplish in The Tree Of Life, with little success (for me anyway- it had wonder at the complexities of life, buku existential angst but little exploration/resolution of the issues raised). Also strongly reminiscent of Jesus' Son, aspects of which I liked very much, but others I found disturbing, without as big a payoff at the end. But THIS- hallelujah, thank-you Yann Martel and Ang Lee. I've rarely been so affected by a film. Surely one of the best films ever made. ***BIG SPOILERS FOLLOW*** DON'T read further until you've seen the film, epecially if, like me you're the kind of person who thrives on discovery and surprise. Reading others' interpretations in advance will color your own, of course. I am an ardent animal lover too; here animals represent what Pi loves, the things he holds dear. The film is an allegorical tale, a smorgasbord of metaphoric imagery and symbolism, jam-packed with them, and levels of meaning, designed to meet you where you are, take from it what you need. I didn't watch this for a long time because I'd read the criticisms from horrified animal lovers. I thought what happened to the animals was handled with great dignity, care, and was CORE to the tale. It's no accident that Pi is an animal lover and a vegetarian. He's also a math whiz, seeks to understand life and the universe on every level possible. What was it young Pi sought from the three religions at the beginning? He even meets a smiling Buddhist just before the accident who advises him to eat the gravy along with the rice, as "sailors", travelers do! Life, or fate, or God, can be viewed as terrible, unjust, incredibly cruel. People die, animals eat each other, even more disturbing is what people do to each other (in the second story- the cook, and even Pi himself). Paradoxically, life is also precious, a gift. People (beings) in our lives are gifts too, whatever their role in it. Towards the end, Pi does not cry for the obvious reason. He wasn't sad because Richard Parker walked away without a backward glance, with no regard for him or seeming gratitude- what brought tears was that HE hadn't thanked RICHARD PARKER! For me, this is about wonder, awakening, what we've been given, gratitude on the most profound level. We're human, we can reflect on such things. The entire universe, not just tigers, is a reflection in your eyes, comes from the depths of yourself, or God's grace, or perhaps they're one and the same. What is within, what is without? On a more obvious level, Pi reaped what he sowed (the love you make...), he cared for Richard Parker, risking his life to do so. Impeccable. Or was it merely a tale of doing what one MUST to survive, to be, or not to be? Though outside the scope of this review, I realized later that for me the film seemed suffused with the spirit and imagery of Chuang Tzu, so like one of his Taoist fables, imagery and themes-wise (attunement with the natural world, including the forces of nature and beings both human and non, resolution of seeming contradictions, impeccability, boundlessness, etc.). In purely human, historical terms, it reminded me of The Greely Expedition to the North Pole vs the Lewis & Clark Expedition. Adolphus Greely, an inexperienced officer, started out bullying his men, threatened them (actually did kill one of them); they were contemptuous of him because at first he hid in his sleeping bag, head covered, shaking, terrified. Government officials shirked their duty and didn't send food/supplies for them- most of the party died. The men watched as, one by one, their friends died terrible deaths, from starvation, from frostbite. But Greely rose to the challenge, gave his own food to his men, eventually evincing empathy, selflessness and courage, and by the end of the horrific ordeal, they adored him, credited him with keeping their spirits up, hope alive (btw, there WAS cannibalism, what brought it to mind). They made it back and apparently Greely lived a long, enjoyable, productive life, undaunted by the horrors, the scandal, happy to be alive. The painstaking, exhaustive data that he and his men risked their lives to collect weren't even appreciated, gathered dust for nearly a century. Climatologists are using them today, invaluable. Then, there was Meriwether Lewis. The Lewis and Clark expedition, though arduous, uncertain, tough, resulted in the death of only one member (from appendicitis). They saw wondrous sights, never before seen by colonial Americans (buffalo, grizzly bears, the great plains, giant trees, rain forests, waterfalls miles wide), and enjoyed hospitality and kindness from nearly all the Indians they encountered. Upon returning home to a hero's welcome- his notes, maps, and specimens celebrated as marvels world-wide- Lewis never got over the hardships they'd endured, e.g., hunger, getting lost, being gone longer than expected, definitely a glass half-empty kind of guy, and faltered at every juncture. He committed suicide three years after returning (though there was some speculation that it might have been murder, but Thomas Jefferson was convinced it was suicide, and he knew Lewis better than anyone). Pi, like Greely, shows his mettle by virtue of his behavior, his perspective, what he perceives, and his interpretation of events (his stories). From a purely psychological point of view, at the very least this is about the resilience of the human spirit, whether or not it springs from a divine source. Does it matter? "Which story do you prefer?" We needn't wait until WE lose everything to decide. Much like Billy Crudup's character in Big Fish, who finally comes to understand, even share and revel in his father's mythos (but must first shed the self and societally-imposed shackles of supposed "objective" reality), Pi's metaphysics and mythos fuse. GLORIOUS. Likely more meanings will unfold for me over time (haven't read the book yet, and I need to think more about the significance of the island). I liked Avatar too, often compared to Life of Pi, but for me it was no match, catharsis-wise. Life of Pi does, however, remind me very much of another movie I loved that covers some of the same ground (though it's quiet, understated, subtle)- Dean Spanley. I found Life of Pi a treasure- astonishing, revelatory, transformative.

I originally saw this movie in 2-D and hesitated to buy it in 3-D because I've found that sometimes if it is incredible viewing in 3-D, it sometimes detracts from the message the movie may be trying to convey.  In this case, the 3-D enhanced the message.  I rarely if ever re-watch a movie I have seen, but in this case I have watched it three times and still feel I have not grasped all the meaning the film has to offer.  It is filled with multiple religious views, suffering and salvation, symbols of good (light) and evil (dark), the smallness of man, and it leaves the viewer making his own choice as to what he believes.

The 3-D and artful photography is phenomenal.  Some of the photography takes your breath away, for example the night at sea, totally black, except for the tiny boat and thousands of bioluminescent jelly fish surrounding it. Everything is sharp and clear out to infinity even with the constant water motion which flows up to your TV set.  It's truly like you are really there.  Water spray and rain pour into the room, and I'm sure the experience is much more intimate and engrossing than it could ever be in the theater.  This movie has everything, unbelievable non-gimmicky 3-D and a real message.

In an era in which CGI has made it possible to put virtually anything one could possibly imagine up on the screen, it has become harder and harder for a filmmaker to make an audience's collective jaw drop. But Ang Lee achieves just that with his adaptation of Yann Martel's "Life of Pi." This movie truly has what we, in modern parlance, like to refer to as "the wow factor," simply because it is unlike anything we've seen on screen before. "Life of Pi" is a surrealistic tale of survival about an Indian boy trapped on a lifeboat in the middle of the ocean with nothing but a ferocious Bengal tiger for a companion.

The first thought we are struck with while watching "Life of Pi" is that this movie would have been impossible to make prior to the CGI revolution in filmmaking. With so many movies abusing that technology for sheer commercial ends, it's gratifying to see a film actually using it for thought-provoking and artistic purposes (see also "Gravity"). At times brutally harsh while at others gloriously lyrical, the movie combines the realistic with the fantastical, the rational with the spiritual - all to illustrate the many disparate and dichotomous elements that, working in glorious chaotic tandem, make up this vast expanse we call the universe.

The first third of the film focuses on Pi's life before the shipwreck. Pi (short for Piscine, which as it shares a rather unfortunate homonym in English, causes Pi at a very early age to abbreviate it) is innately curious about not only the world around him but the world that lies beyond the physical. He is so fascinated with the spiritual, in fact, that he has adopted the tenets of each of the world`s major religions and made them his own. Pi lives with his stern, skeptical father (Adil Hussain), his more open-minded, sympathetic mother (Tabu) and his somewhat less curious older brother (who is played by three different actors in various stages of the story). One of the prime exhibits in the zoo owned by Pi's father is a Bengal tiger that, through a bureaucratic fluke, has been tagged with the name Richard Parker, a prosaic moniker hardly befitting the king of the jungle. When the father decides to sell the zoo, the family, along with the animals, board a Japanese freighter to begin a new life in Canada (the plan is to sell the animals once they get there). On the way, however, tragedy strikes when the ship sinks in a tremendous storm, sending all but Pi and Richard Parker to the bottom of the sea. "Life of Pi" is the story of their survival.

Alternately awe-inspiring, heartbreaking and suspenseful, the screenplay by David Magee expands on the  "circle of life" metaphor to explore how each element of nature is interlocked with every other element, with each action prompting a reaction unto infinity. Though natural born "enemies," Pi and Richard Parker achieve a kind of symbiosis, ultimately forced to rely on one another for survival (RP for his physical needs, Pi for his spiritual), and in so doing, they achieve a harmony that puts them in sync with the rest of the universe. Yet, for all its pantheistic elements, the movie doesn't over-sentimentalize nature, doesn't shy away from showing us the unthinking brutality that is also a part of that universe, underlined by the fact that living creatures can survive only by feeding on other living creatures. It certainly never downplays the very real danger Pi is in at every moment from his feline companion. This cat may be animated, but he's no cartoon character.

Never one to shy away from a challenge, Lee won a second Best Director Oscar for his work here, and someday the Academy might even see fit to bestow a Best Picture award on him as well (he was certainly robbed of that honor for "Brokeback Mountain"). As he has done many times before, Lee demonstrates a total command of the medium in "Life of Pi." There's a hallucinatory quality to much of the film, as Pi frequently experiences preternatural visions that transcend the confines of the material world and of rational thought, leading him to a oneness with God.

Suraj Shama has been handed the challenge - one might almost call it the burden - of carrying large stretches of this film entirely on his own, with only a CGI effect to interact with. It is a challenge the gifted young actor is more than equipped to handle and he fulfills it beautifully.

Though the movie throws the audience for a loop at the end, making us question the veracity of the tale the adult Pi (Irrfan Kahn) is relating to the writer (Rafe Spall) who hopes to chronicle the experience, no one can ever convince the true believer in all of us that this is anything other than a love story between a boy and a tiger. After all - thanks to the technical wizards who've made it all possible - we've seen it with our own eyes.

Firstly, all those animals were hiding out and not killing each other?  This kid did not hear them?  Had the writer ever seen any of these animals in the wild or in captivity even?

A hyena and a zebra are not going to snuggle in hiding.  That zebra would be kicking and freaking out and overturning that boat.  Second, that kid stood no chance in a boat with a tiger.  Let alone with a hyena!  Those beasts are mean and nasty.  Look them up.

Look, supposedly this story is full of symbolism one should enjoy interpreting.  Ok, there may be educational value in this movie.  But entertainment value?  Not much.

This movie requires effort to enjoy.  Effort to sustain suspension of disbelief.  Effort to interpret its elements.  Effort to stay awake.

NOT RECOMMENDED.

Visually beautiful (even though the CGI is obvious in any shot that involves motion with any speed to it) & very well acted; still it suffers for its deviations from the novel. There are a number of scenes altered from Martel's work or made up entirely & inserted (clearly in several cases for the aesthetic value of the imagery rather than because they added anything to a story that needed no additions), & others that were key to the story as it was put down on paper which were done away with altogether, leaving gaping holes in the narrative & damaging the ending to a major degree. I couldn't see any reason for these changes, except maybe to get the PG rating since some of the deleted portions were pretty grim, or maybe it was felt that viewers would only go for a cleaned up story with a pat ending; but I was disappointed to see what was done, as it diminished the main character & lessened the impact of his journey both across the Pacific & within himself. They made a good movie out of a great book, when they could have done far better by simply sticking with the source material.

I enjoyed this film very much, and would be inclined to give it 5 stars - but it already has many 5-star revews...so I'll object to just a few things.  The opening sequence had beautiful 3D renderings and whetted my apetite for a 3D extravaganza - but the rest of the film wasn't so 3-dimensional as the opening. Fortunately, the core story was quite engrossing, well told, and visually exciting even without much use of the 3rd dimension.  I'll find fault with a metaphorical turn at the end, without mentioning plot details.  There was a brief exegesis in the film, which was in my opinion almost unnecessary, and too brief to make much of the metaphors.  That sent me to the book, which i hadn't read, where I found a much more detailed exegesis, which was interesting, but would have required more preparation in the earlier part of the story in order to make it possible for the themes to make sense.  That might have been a good idea, since there was a little puppy-love story that ended up being a loose end in the film.  That story could have been cut, in favor of stronger development of the vegetarian theme that IMO would add substance to the film. Nitpicking aside, this is one of the most interesting 3D films that I've seen - especially in its opening sequence!

The film itself is very good.  It's a beautiful story, and thought provoking, with an ending that leaves you wondering (in the same way that the film Inception does) about what is real.  It is also a story of survival and growth.  I am glad to own it.

I waited such a long time to see this, as I missed it in the theaters. I kept hearing how breathtaking the scenes were and heartwarming the story was. So when I got my 3D TV, I bought this right away. When it arrived, even the DVD case said possibly the next Avatar. I couldn't wait to put it in! Well... I watched it last night, and I'm beginning to think the whole world is on drugs! The story was boring. And what beautiful scenery are people referring to, the turbulent waves that are trying to swallow every living thing, the blood thirsty tiger scenes, or the carnivorous island?! Aside from those scenes, there was no movie! I'm even angry today about the letdown. That's why I'm writing this review. Maybe it will be cathartic. lol

i love this movie and I wanted it on bluray so I bought this bluray /dvd combo pack. the dvd disk works fine but the bluray disk skips like its scratch on all my bluray players( ps3, ps4 and my Panasonic bluray player) so I know its the disk that's no good cause it brand-new with scratch like effects happening. so I feel robed because I pay for a bluray and all that works is the dvd so in return i am giving this a sad 1 star review

If you want to watch a good survival movie, try Cast Away with Tom Hanks. Even with no animals, just a volleyball named Wilson, it was a more captivating movie than this one. Although I understand this movie is more about metaphysical questions, it just didn't work as an adventure-at-sea movie for me. It was long -- I could multitask, walk away, come back and pick up where I left off. And the ending entirely ruined it for me. When the investigators come to question Pi about the shipwreck, he tells two stories... and to him what matters is which is the better story, not which is the truth. I didn't like the inference that truth doesn't matter. If he weaves a fanciful tale in order for his psyche to survive, that's fine, and if he wants to let the fairy tale be the story, that's fine. But if there's another story about the shipwreck, and it is the true story (as true as something in fiction can be), gruesome though it was, that would be the story I'd prefer to hear, and I don't need a fairy tale to go alongside it.

I enjoyed this movie.  I thought it had a few funny moments, and a few scary moments.  Its a sad story, and has many good moments to it.  It is a movie about a young boy dealing with religion during a very distressing period in his life.

God is great.  God is elusive.  God is everywhere and nowhere.  What and why the heck do we need to believe in God, and does he give even the slightest flying F about human suffering and existence?  This movie poses these questions under the disguise of a poor guy named, Pi, and how he didn't get eaten alive by a Bengal tiger....

A masterful story replete with wired emotion and deep sympathy that touches on the great themes of humankind and treats religious belief as not only viable but deeply meaningful and intrinsically powerful.  An extended metaphor on the sorrow of life redeemed unto a relativistic, psychologically fragile birth and life of a soul.  High drama, epic in scope yet so microscopically tightly focused and visually stunning, sumptuously colored in deep textured shades that draw the eyes into them.  Heart wrenching, heart aching, and life affirming.

This movie must be seen.

A spectacularly gorgeous movie, surreal and enchanting.  Some viewers have been critical of this film on grounds either religious or atheistic.  As an agnostic, religious aspects went right by me.  What I saw was a fabulist allegory.......our species adrift on a small planet in a vast and indifferent universe, our only companions "nature red in tooth and claw."  It is worth appreciating that, like all the most intriguing stories, we can see in this film what we want.

I wanted something awesome for 3D and bought Life of Pi.  The story is very interesting and the adventure fantastic though unlikely.  The 3D came off beautifully and well worth the money.  Yann Martel, the author, did a great job taking us into his world of evasion and fantasy, weaving in and out of reality.  Ultimately PI survives and shows that perseverance pays.  It's a beautiful film and the sceneries are breathtaking, especially the "survival at sea" during the night, the whale, stars, light all of it magical.
I read the book first and thought the movie lived up to my expectations.  Very engrossing and kept me entertained throughout.

Pi faced, and conquered, his greatest fears.  I'll watch this movie again, and again.  It's one of those stories the whole family can enjoy together, with each individual receiving their own message.  The "absolute faith" that God will never leave, nor forsake us, was etched into the heart of a young Hindi boy - indelibly, and forever.  I was left with tears streaming down my cheeks.  Highly recommended.

I have to admit to purchasing this movie to replace my copy which never made it back from a friend. But the movie itself is a wonderful, beautifully crafted example of movie production. With my schedule I don't get an opportunity to see movies in the theater, but was fortunate to see this one on the big screen. This Blu-Ray rendition brings out the full beauty that I remember from the big screen. An excellent value for your entertainment dollar.
We loved this as well the experiences and how they shaped a life through contact with the animal kingdom was amazing! Also this had a cultural feel to I as well.
Life of Pi is a visual masterpiece and a spiritually epic film. Great acting, music, cinematography, and overall, a film that might make you think a little more than the average mainstream movie.

I used this to introduce the book to a middle school ELA class in an urban Special Education (self contained) classroom. It did the trick. It got the kids interested in the excerpt we were reading in CodeX. In fact, the kids were so motivated, they read more of the actual book on their own, and they watched the full length movie. The excerpt here is exciting, and is just the right length to get kids hooked.

I could not believe how beautiful this movie was. It moved me in ways so deep that I had to watch it twice one weekend to really help it to sink in. The themes of family, love, religion, seeking truths, pain, grief, loss, memories and moving on are all wonderfully displayed. This movie deserved all the awards it got and then some. Without going into spoilers, I just want to express that this movie is a must see.

found the whole episode wierd but exciting in the least.

Life of Pi may not have been the best film of 2012 (I think Lincoln was a better movie), but it was certainly one of the top couple of movies.  It's a gorgeous film with a great story.  I found the acting by the lead character believable and involving.  The 3D aspects of Life of Pi are subtle and probably make little difference in terms of the the story.  But it certainly has its moments of depth that enhance the beautiful cinematography.  While the film is memorable for the many scenes on the open sea with just Pi and Richard Parker (the tiger), the shots looking upward through the water in the clear-as-a-bell swimming pool are the images I think of most often.  Life of Pi is based on a book that was among my favorites when it came out several years ago, so I was prepared to be disappointed in the film.  I wasn't.  Ang Lee handled the material with great respect, and told the story quite well given the time limitations of a film vs. a book.  It's a movie I expect to watch many times and joyfully share with others.

I was very disappointed after watching this. All the good reviews and the trailer,s I thought most of this movie would take place on a deserted island, but no, it all happens on a life boat.
I do not get the ratings for this film. I found it boring quite frankly. The whole lifeboat despair thing has been done many times before and done better.
I also can't say I found any true inspiration to any kind of spiritual journey in it either.
In one word I'd describe this movie as boring.
And it also made me a bit sick of the Indian accent.

I just got through watching 2012s Life of Pi for the second time around only this time in 3D.  Every year The Academy gives out my favorite award for Best Cinematography and its no wonder that Ang Lees Life of Pi won it.  The film is visual eye candy and breathtakingly sweet.  Life of Pi just pours on the visuals.  The 3D is the very best I have seen on any home transfer to date; razor sharp and incredibly crisp.

My favorite scene was when Pi and Richard Parker land on the island of Meerkats.  Seeing Pi basking overhead in one of the island hotspots at nighttime was so beautifully rendered and with the added constellations and star-light the scene was sheer magical perfection.

Life of Pi is a spectacular film that I will re-watch over and over again for many years to come.

I don't normally write reviews on movies but I must say this one is a must see, I have watched  many 3D movies on my Vizio 65" TV and none of the others have even come close..
Not only is this story thought evoking and emotionally rewarding but the 3D effects are  nothing short of spectacular Life of Pi in 3D will literally blow you away!.
I could not download it onto my tablet using Amazon Prime, so I cancelled the Prime membership. Wish it would have worked, it sounds like a cool idea...:(
A beautiful story about faith and courage. An actual parable up on the screen that makes you think about your own way of living.

I really enjoyed this movie for it's storyline. There was pretty decent story with many twists and turns. My kids had trouble with the accent of Pi, but adapted quickly.
I would say this movie is probably not for small children, but for adolescents, it is fine.
I missed seeing this at the theatre, the story twist and visual delights make this a must see. I would not allow small children see this.

I watched it first in the theater. Frankly I did not get the whole story, but enjoyed the cinematography spectacle tremendously. Then I got the DVD, and watched it 3 times. Every time I watched it, I caught details that I left out before. Words cannot express the beauty of the story and the scenes. It's a masterpiece that only the most talented minds could conjure up and make it real.

OK, up front, I'm reviewing the dvds included in this set.  I saw the movie at a theater several times in real 3-D.  Astonishing describes it--I'm in agreement with the positive reviews.  But why isn't the regular dvd in this set not in HD?  Why even bother to make the transfer if not using HD?!  Since the blu-ray dvd doesn't play on my computer, I'm stuck playing a blurry second-rate version on it.  Also, it is disappointing to play the blu-ray version on my blu-ray player, and even with lots of adjusting of brightness, backlight, contrast and color, the definition and color is just not there, most especially in dark scenes.  Perhaps it's a matter of expecting too much from my ordinary tv.  But I chose to write this review because "Life of Pi" is most of all, a tremendous visual achievement.
It's an awesome movie to watch, the scenery, the photografy, visual effects, it's all gorgeous, I also liked the story.
This is a Christmas present that was requested. The person receiving the gift will be very excited to get it.

I know my youngest son will absolutely love it and so it will be one of his Christmas presents.

It is a great story about a shipwreck survivor learning to survive on a lifeboat with a Tiger as his only companion.  This isn't a nice fluffy talking Tiger, it is a Tiger that wants to eat Pi (the main character).

I highly recommend this to any 3D TV owner to truly see what your system is capable of.

The Life of Pi is a stunningly beautiful, masterfully written, fable for atheists and agnostics.  What do I mean?

My full review (with spoilers) is here: [...] but in essence, the author wants us to accept that our belief in God is really just a way for us to explain the horrible reality all around us.  We want to believe in a beautiful and purposeful explanation for the cruelty and misery of the world around us, instead of what is actually going on, which is, I imagine, purposelessness, random and survived only by the fittest.

Supposedly President Obama himself endorsed the idea of God presented in the book, and brought to the screen in this amazing movie.  I would have to whole-heartedly disagree with the entire premise, while still enjoying the spectacular visuals.
Bought this so that the wife and I could watch it on our LG 3D HDTV. Thoroughly enjoyed this from the storyline thru the graphics. You won't be disappointed.

The 3D Blu-ray is as near to perfection as I have seen too. There are things that don't catch your eye or attention until you see it in 3D. The 3D effects are very believable. There are just enough in-front-of-the-screen 3D moments to make the experience exciting.

The story is quite engrossing, and it keeps you thinking. This is the type of movie that as a story and spectacle is beautiful to behold. Even on subsequent viewings, the film maintains its charm, and I have enjoyed seeing it in both 2D and 3D.

I know some people consider pop-outs gimmicky, preferring unobtrusive 3D. They talk about how enhanced depth is all they want. Well, 2D already has depth, otherwise it would be unwatchable. As far as I'm concerned if things aren't popping out of the screen then 3D is absolutely pointless. The pop-out is, after all, the 3rd dimension.

There was virtually no 3D in this film as far as I could tell. Just look at the cover image. How great would it have been to have that giant whale pop out of the screen and into your living room? How about water rushing toward you? Or your living room seemingly engulfed in waves with mist all around? That's what I was expecting when I purchased this film. But none of that was to be found. It's a 2D film packaged as 3D in my opinion. What's the point of wearing clunky and uncomfortable active shutter glasses and putting up with an inferior image if you're not going to get the pop-out payoff?

My 2 star rating wasn't just for the lack of any discernible 3D. Let me put it this way, I probably will never watch this movie again. I just wasn't transported by it. 2 hours spent on the ocean with one character and a tiger were a bit much.
Excellent movie. This is one your grand kids will enjoy over and over. I was pleasantly surprised that I did too! The bonus features on producing the movie are very interesting also.
Spectacular photography and 3D effects. Very good story. They say there are only 3 movies that are completely 3D: Avatar, Life of Pi, and Gravity (which I still have to watch). I agree!

A very in-depth emotional movie.  You imagine yourself in the boat with your only company, of all things a wild lion, and you have to figure out how to survive a treacherous situation, the sea.  This movie touches your soul and we thoroughly enjoyed it.

Great story with a lot of deeper meaning that is not too complicated. Opens up the concept of a Higher power by accepting almost any religion as a vehicle to spiritualism. The power of GPU computing is on display in this movie. Most of the content is CG. Pretty well done. Computer generated content in movies will only get more pervasive and will improve greatly in the future. Watch the remaster of Lawrence of Arabia.on BLU-Ray as a benchmark. The old way was a great way to do it too. I don't think CG will ever surpass this masterpiece. If it does, then we will finally get those flying cars seen in old issues of Pop Sci.
This movie is stunning. Ang lee deserve best director,  its a beautiful movie. The storyof Pi and Richard the tiger is rare and unforgettable. It deserve all the buzz.

Absolutely gorgeous!! It is visually stunning, and emotionally/psychologically profound. I especially like that it follows the book, which doesn't always happen. It is such a remarkable story told by some one who had endured so much, and grew in so many ways. I don't want to give too much b4ecause it may spoil it, but it really is an amazing movie, and everyone should see.
Magnificent movie that does true justice to the book. Spectacular film, passionately made and gorgeous to behold. Wonderful Blu-Ray version, fascinating and inspiring features.
I really like this movie after it got started. The beginning was very boring. but I enjoy watching animal shows. so will  watch this again !
I was mesmerized by this film.  The beauty, Pi's life experience.  It touches the soul.  I rarely watch a movie twice and I ended up watching this one twice in one week.  I highly recommend it.
The best visual 3D effect (Passive 3D system) to date. Every thing in the movie looks so real with perfect depth of field. This is a good movie to try out your new 3D TV. Acting, however, ....

Twists, turns, drama, English, foreign tones. Interesting, some action, makes you think about "family". Action, sad, surprising, mystical. Unexpected plot. Consverstation piece. Good worth the rental. Intelligent.

This story is apart of the common core curriculum, believe it or not... and the kids like it...although they laughed most of the way through the story!

One of my all time favorite movies!

I have decided to add the following to all my reviews:

Beware! Some "reviewers" will trash a product for no reason simply because they are paid to or because they sell competitive products. Other "reviewers" will give products - that they have never seen and never used - glowing 5 star ratings - for a fee.  Some honest reviewers do not understand what a product is for or how to use it and will trash a product simply because they are just plain dumb.
This somewhat predictably was my favorite film, almost tied with LES MISERABLE of the 2012 crop of movies.  This is one I expect to see again and again.  It was also one of my film group's favorites.
One of the best movies I have seen in a long time. It's not anything like Rambo and it's not about food.

Its also just a beautiful movie to watch, if you aren't the kind of person that analyzed movies.  Its full of suspense and pleasant imagery.  Fully recommend watching this movie in blu ray as well.  Ultra crisp!

Every color is perfect and balanced with other colors. The interior of the lifeboat against the color of the ocean is just magnificent. The acting is wonderful and the dialogue could not be better. I have decided which story is true and will watch it again and again and be affected again and again.

A great film.

Beautiful gorgeous movie . Story is AMAZING and the graphics are just as amazing as the story itself , its touching and moving and by the end of the movie you feel as though you have learned a life lesson . Life of Pi is a wonderful movie, keeps you on edge.  Very exciting things happen all the time.  Great story!
A very unusual type of movie, interesting storyline bordering on science fiction but still believable. Great CGI  tiger, considering the Pi actor never confronted the live animal.

I didn't know what to expect when we started watching this movie. Everything about this movie is first class - the story, the acting, the videography. The best movie I've ever seen - and the end of the story leaves you wondering - what if...

This is an entertaining story but it's not a movie I wish to watch twice. The special effects were good but overrated as was the story itself. I didn't find it particularly thought provoking which was definitely one of the most hyped aspects of the movie. Characters were represented by animals who, in turn, represented various human traits such as courage, greed, etc... This would have been more interesting if it all wasn't so heavy handed.

In the end, a movie is watched for the purpose of entertainment and I was entertained. The story progressed at a nice pace and the underlying emotion was strongly felt which is a fairly rare thing in so many modern superficial blockbusters. So while my criticisms might seem a bit harsh it was definitely a good movie, even if it was only good for a single view.
The tiger was outstanding in this movie.  The story line was a bit hard to follow.  Good movie to add to my collection

To get the full enjoyment out of this move you have to see it in 3D. It is spectacular.  The animals and sea life really make a big impression in the 3D format. Boy, talk about a story coming to life. If it is possible for you to watch it in 3D I highly recommend that you do. I can only imagine, since I have not seen the regular version, that the range of emotion you get from watching the images become bigger than life has to be superior over the regular DVD. The beauty of it will take your breath away.

p.s. Didn't go into the story line in general, there is enough info and speculation on what this story is about in other reviews. Hope this doesn't tick you off that I just wanted to talk about the 3D version.

A second avatar, an extraordinary story good.
No a days in scholls there is no learning about real life.
Story as Avatar and Life of PI can pass better to young people.
Life's story about relationships, conflicts, and solutions. A good movie for teenages to watch and discuss. It was well done .

There isn't much to say except it just provides a look into what the film is about.  I might actually watch the movie.

I normally don't like 3-D movies, but this one is excellent.  We recently bought a 3-D TV and DVD player.  Therefore, thought this was a great movie to test our new system.  It is certainly that.  The package actually has three verisons on the movie in 3-D, digital and standard DVD.
Our whole family loved this movie, including my kids ages 9 and 7.  A very deep movie (with some humor), that gives much food for thought.  Easy to watch more than once!
This should be movie of the year...one of the best pictures I've seen in a long time.  Beautifully done, stunning.

I haven't read the book, but I did like the movie.  Amazing acting by Suraj Sharma; I don't think I'd be so comfortable that close to a Bengal Tiger.  Great adventure story. My teenage grandsons really liked it.

This was one of the movies I had to watch on the big screen and was quite taken with it.  To watch it at home in 3D is just a much a treat.  Usually I'm not too fond of narration in a movie, but it certainly fits here.  I don't plan to watch it often, but will certainly watch it again and again.

of course the ordering of the stories is different...story 1 ends the film. and story 2, as i say, IS the film (almost), accompanied with some "real world" context (introduction and final exit of protagonist)...pi begins intelligently, and from that point it extends to always increasing levels of beauty... for minds prepared to appreciate it...for those that are not, as it is also very philosophical, it seems to me that it will require a patience that cannot be sustained... as with all intricate pieces...whether you watch or not is not a test, only whether it leaves you better off than it found you...your call...ciao.
This movie was great for the whole family.  It's clean, great storyline and at points keeps you on the edge of your seat. Incredible scenes worth watching.
I have watched it twice and I liked it both times.  What beautiful photography.  It was spell binding. Very moving and a great ending.

Great movie and excellent video and sound!  Highly recommend to others as it is very entertaining and thought-provoking.  If your regular fare is more like films titled "Knocked Up" or "Identity Thief", you may want to pass.

Saw this at the theater and decided to buy a copy for home. It has been just as enjoyable watching at home as it was at the movies. Have never read the book and a lot of people who have did not like it. The movie is pretty similar but those that didn't like the book seem to like the movie more.

I probably would not watch this a second time, but it was cheap and a good 3-d flick.  Very artistic presentation reminiscent of a Target ad  under psychedelic drugs.  Story equally absurd, but fun.  This is an experience and do not take your brain to this movie,

The Life of PI is really about dealing with grief.  It was slow moving at first building a required foundation, once the action started you cannot turn from the screen.  It has a twist at the end that might be a surprise.  It leaves you to ponder, what survival skills do you have, how do you deal with loss and trauma, is rigid religion preferable with death or can you find ways to manage during the crisis. Above all, we discover that no matter what happens, life goes on and each of us finds strength from deep within and from our roots.
I have NO IDEA how this actually became a movie because of the book it came from, but I am certainly glad it was made, no matter the difficulty.

This may or may not be a fantasy. I choose to believe this young man's story. The cinematography was beyond compare. Lovely to watch. I have seen this many times and that may mean it will be a classic - perhaps just for children, but then it is really for adults to open their eyes, to believe in whatever they choose.
this movie touched me deeply ,my heart cried. I recommend you watch this movie with your young children's  ,all about survival
We enjoyed watching it with 3 children, ages 12, 9 and 6. Great graphics, recommend watching it in H D.

This a simple story that at times truly excites. I have viewed the movie three times and still can't believed the visual effects created by the film makers, Everyone should have this masterpiece in their collection.

What a tremendous film! The packaging states "The next Avatar", but "Life of Pi" is actually far superior. First of all, the cinematography is absolutely gorgeous. It's difficult to put into words just what a stunning picture this is. Director Ang Lee has far out-done himself.

But what is a beautiful picture without a compelling story? And the story of Pi (and of Richard Parker) is indeed compelling. This movie is so gripping that you feel like you are part of the story. Starting off with Pi's childhood (and Richard Parker's early years as well) and moving into Pi's teenage years, this film tells a story for the ages. Solid acting combines with the majesty of nature to wrap you up in a narrative that is highly spiritual and suitable for family members of all ages. You leave this film feeling like a better person for having seen it.
The cinematic effect is excellent, but in the end, it's mostly about a boy and a tiger on a boat deserted on the open sea. It's a bit boring at times.

This film is the real "eye of the tiger". Very heartwarming story about determination, love, resilience. Actors in this film do a great job as well. Film has some similarities to "Cast Away" with Tom Hanks, although I thought this one much more capturing. Really enjoyed it!

I must admit that when I got to the end of this long journey, my new 3D HDTV started malfunctioning.  Which greatly interrupted the meaning and flow of the ending.  After fixing the issue, I re-watched the end and cannot wait to see the entire movie again. The ending, if you have no idea of what's coming, begs re-watching.  The 3D effects, the quality of the transfer, the stunning sound track and of course, a story that you'll never forget!!!  Five stars.
I really enjoyed this movie.  The imagery is STUNNING and its a unique story that keeps you watching to the end.
It was the best movie I have ever seen and would recommend to anyone so I even bought it love it.
Self-important, quasi-spiritual, bogus mysticism, wrapped in a bundle of CGI. Valuable as a demonstration of available film technology. Of no lasting value as drama.

Too many films depend on special effects alone to drive their film.  It's that rare bird, Martin Scorsese's "Hugo" comes to mind, where the effects are there to enhance the story.  "Life of Pi" joins that select company.  What director Ang Lee has devised here is nothing short of a miracle.  You will find yourself transfixed by this tale of young Pi Patel (Suraj Sharma) cast adrift in the ocean after the freighter carrying he, his family, and a menagerie of zoo animals capsizes. This film is a testament to will, determination, and faith that keeps Pi alive to survive his ordeal.  Much has been said about Ang Lee's direction and there's no diminishing that but I felt that Sharma to be the driving force of the film.  This is a case of a director and an actor working in communion to make something of lasting impact.  There are no adjectives that can sufficiently describe what a wonder this film is.
Loved it, came in record time!

What a journey.  The visual effects of this movie alone whether you like the plot or not make this movie worth watching.  The acting is done really well too, making this movie a favorite.  What an adventure.
Great story, wonderful 3-D effects.  I will watch this movie over and over because I believe I'll see something new each time.  One is never sure of the truth at the end of the story.
Really good movie and it's beautiful to look at.  Love the story - I read the book and watched the movie!
This movie is excellent ! The cinematography is outstanding and the story keeps you glued to the end. Great !!

Enjoyed the movie, and the quality of the Blu-ray was great. Glad to save and buy it through Amazon - always a good option!
This movie was not one I jumped to go so see at the theater. My mistake, it is a beautifully told story. I would recommend this for children over 14 & all adults. Your heart & mind will be filled.

This is one of the most beautifully photographed movies I have ever seen in my life.  The story is enormous.  I would recommend renting or buying this movie to anyone!  One of the best purchases I have ever made.  This movie is definitely a part of my personal collection of all-time favorite DVD's!

The story itself concludes cleverly with the viewer to make his/her own decision. In general, a keeper to add to ones collection.

Ang Lee's "Life of Pi" is strikingly beautiful in many ways, from great cinematography to the story being portrayed.  You need to be prepared is half of the movie is graphics with music.  I will not take the time to compare and contrast this film with others as it is so unique in itself.

I have to admit that I have not read the novel by Yann Martel and I am sure that a lot has been left out.  I will need to read the book to find out what was implied; unless of course the screenplay went off in a different direction.  You will want to watch this film over again after the shock value so that you can pick up the nuances that you missed while you were speculating on what was about to happen.

The basic story is about a young man named Pi (Suraj Sharma) whose father owns a zoo.  Throughout his life Pi wonders about what Douglas Adams calls "life the universe and everything."  Because of business concerns his father packs up the zoo animals on a freighter setting out for Canada.  Due to a mishap Pi no longer has to speculate but actually lives "life the universe and everything."  We travel with them through his trials and tribulations wondering what we would do in that situation.

One can come away from this film with a new insight or at least say that they saw a movie that was strikingly beautiful in many ways.

I was crying  the next day and My mom asked me the next day if I had to go live in a stress center and I said "no". Sorry Folks! but I'm thinking of giving my copy away or selling it. I don't know. I do love animal flicks though. In my opinion, this movie was like an Asian version of "Secondhand Lions" (Which is a movie I did love). If you enjoyed "Secondhand Lions", and "Wild America" alot better (Like Me), Then stick with those movies. Thanks for reading. Peter Smith

This magnificent, exquisite film is so superior to most of what Hollywood turns out that any self-aware producer should be acutely embarrassed by it. Nevertheless, I'd like to offer a slightly negative perspective.

"Life of Pi" is easy to criticize for being a bit sentimental and unduly "cute" *. Its worst failing is a glib ambiguity as to what it's "about". After promising the Writer that, after hearing the story, he will believe in God, Pi says "It simply happened. Does it have to have a meaning?" This suggests the author has no intended meaning for this story, which is reinforced by the suggestion that what we believe is what we would like to believe -- be it about Pi's adventures or the nature of God.

Nevertheless, don't miss it -- especially if you have a 60" or larger display. The PG rating is apt; there are moments that will frighten some pre-teens.

On a technical level, CGI artists still don't understand F=ma (the lifeboats slide on the water like fried eggs on Teflon), and the orangutan doesn't really look like an orangutan, and moves an awful lot like a human being.

* Richard Parker's name is supposed to be amusing. It was a result of inadvertently assigning the name of the man who caught him to the animal. I suspect the misnaming is supposed to parallel Pi's assertion that he can see the animal's soul in its eyes.
I thought provoking re: reality; great animal photography; clever dialogue; clever humor; haven't read the book, but plan to do so soon

This is my new favorite movie!  I never read the book, but this movie was everything I could have hoped for.  It is visually magnificent with a well written story and narration.  This is a story told by an adult Pi, of his childhood in India and how he survived and persevered at sea with only a full-grown tiger for company.  The movie does have spiritual/religious undertones in it which are left open for personal interpretation.  There are some violent scenes, so I would recommend caution when allowing children to watch.  Not since Avatar has a movie been this visually appealing!  With the great storytelling and visuals, this is a movie to watch again and again!

The moral underlying the storyline: whether the reality of religious beliefs is real or whether the mundane is real is left for us to ponder and to choose which suits us best. Thoroughly enjoyable from every aspect

I have viewed this film some three times.  Everytime I see it, I get a more and more meaning!  The closest literary meaning is cross a between two stories both of which are different in the length of the narrative:  "The Lady or The Tiger" and "Robinson Crusoe."  There is so much symbolism to this film/novel, that I think it could take a lifetime of study, to even begin to fully understand this wonderful work, if at all!  LIFE'S MEANING CAN ASSUME A MYRAID AND ASTRONOMICAL AMOUNTS OF DEFINITION!  NJMJr!

First, I just have to say a technical word. Most of the good reviews of this film rave about the "3D" version, and frankly this makes me a little sick. Beautifully photographed, yes, but you don't need to see it in 3D, a passing fancy, to be impressed by the incedible visual impact of this film. It is a Lee masterpiece, and you can hear Louis Armstrong on an old 33/rd pressing of the song "It's a wonderful world", and be just as impressed, in fact more so, than hearing it on a modern CD. So let's let the technocrats go here! Those glasses stink.

Second, this is clearly a "fable", in its most wonderous sort. The second story Pi tells to the Japanese insurance agents is the True Story, while the movie shows us the Fable. Now, the fable is not a figment of imagination for Pi, it is his only way of saving himself from insanity on an "Ocean of Loneliness" and desperation. He believes it to be true. This is the same way that Ennis in the wonderful "Brokeback Mountain", also protects himself in his own ocean storm, convincing himself that he visits Jack's room, in Jack's family home with the strange settings and the equally strange parents, and retrieves some of Jack's clothing. The visit is a dream, and it gives poor Ennis just a bit of closure with the loss of his only love. The same with Pi. Having lost everything, his closure is yes, indeed, to "become the Tiger". When he is finally beached and rescued, the Tiger leaving him, without a goodbye, is an essential part of his soul departing, and the complete realization of this change and his tragic loss, breaks Pi's heart.

You see, Lee, is a master of the psyche and the heart. He knows how to adapt a novel or screenplay to wring every bit of the "real" reality of the story, and how through the most compelling of needs, the imagination of humanity must create its fables to save its "reality", to create "alternate realities", completely believeable, and to the "mind", the truest creation of them all. This goes to the utter sadness of this movie, since all Pi has loved had died,and only Pi, the great Tiger of the mind, the admirer of so many religions in his youth, must live on. As his Father suggests early on "get reason, first". Pi, on the otherhand, survives, while "reason" finds a horrible and unending death. Fables lead to myths, and then to legends, and these finally are what casts us adrift to ceasely keep navigating our "boats against the stream". "Reason", as the Bard said so aptly, "doth make cowards of us all". I prefer the first version.

I never read the book and didn't want to watch the movie, but saw it at a friend's house. Even though I didn't see it on the large screen or in 3D, it was mesmerizing. At first I was comfortably seated on a sofa, but midway through the film I found myself hunched forward, literally on the edge of my seat. By the end of the movie I was crying. That's how gripping the cinematography and special effects were, and to a certain extent the story itself. Although some people dislike the alternate ending, I found it wonderful. There are flaws, but the overall experience overcomes them. For example, in the first third of the tale, there is a fair amount of humor. The humor seems oddly out of place in the story as a whole and is soon dispensed with, never to return. There are some anomalies which are not explored, such as an instance where a goat on one side of a barred doorway is apparently taken through to the other side by a tiger. The tiger is a wonderful character and so realistically done that I thought a live animal was being used for much of the film until I learned otherwise. He has a name, Richard Parker, which seems to be an allusion to an actual person, but I don't want to spoil anything by explaining the reference. All the actors are quite good and manage to make you care for them, so when tragedy strikes, it really hits home. Apart from being trapped on a raft in the Pacific, water is a recurring theme, right down to Pi's real name...his full name is that of a French public swimming pool. The idea of rebirth is linked to that, and Pi's growth from introspective teen to self-sufficient man is a part of it. This is a dazzling and enchanting movie, and well worth watching.

I had seen Life of Pi and loved it so gave it as a gift to my parents.  They are having a few health problems but still love to stay up on current movies.  Well, they loved it and plan to re watch it with their grandchildren and great grandchildren.  A movie for the generations!

This movie is about the karmic history of our soul/Pi that subsists inside humans who are living here on this planet (Earth is represented in the movie as the island where Pi finds the meerkats, meerkats = people living inside this planet/the island. Its important to understand the irony when they say the island/Earth during the day gave everything that existed within life but in the night it took everything back. This is exactly what this world is doing to us; it gives us life yet its killing us at the same time as we are staying in it). The truth about who we really are has been hacked from us therefore, we are living a physical animation of a false reality thats far away from the truth.  Fortunately for Pi he knew deep inside something was always missing from his life God and led him to journey outside of himself/his body/the island/earth to get his answers. Ironically, we are living a fictional movie where we believe we are what we see. Unfortunately, this false identity of who we are and the un-knowingly purpose of our life is the main fall in humanity/ Mr Richard Parker lack of understanding of who he is. Unless we wake up to the truth about the beautiful colors that life has to offer, will end up like Richard Parkers faded gray in the end where he is seen walking back into the jungle/earth. The consequence in people not journeying into themselves is never finding God and eventually leading to our destruction. Because Richard Parker/meerkats/people/ never understood their connection and relation to God, karma had a way of letting us know the cycle of re-incarnating here will not rest until we get it right.

This is not my normal type of story, but on a whim, I decided to download the movie. I was aware of the book but never really checked out what it was about. Mostly, it's an adventure -- or rather, the ability of a man to tell a great story about an adventure. At the end, you're not really sure if it was a true story, but by that time it doesn't matter because it was such an awesome one. The general gist is that a boy lives in India with his family, who owns a zoo. They are getting their zoo land taken away so they have to move away (to america, I think). They still own all the animals, so they load all the animals onto a ship and set sail. But there is a bad storm and the ship goes down, but not before the boy manages to free some of the animals. The boy is the only one to survive. He drifts along in the middle of the sea in a dingy. He has a monkey and a zebra with him and a very aggressive hyena, who keeps attacking the other animals. The boy, Pi, stays as far away from the hyena as possible, which is hard when you are in a tiny boat. His tiger from the zoo swims up and gets in the boat. Fortunately, he sets that hyena straight, but unfortunately, he is a serious threat to Pi. So Pi spends most of his days floating on a man-made raft outside the boat, while he tries to come to terms with the tiger. Eventually, they learn to "co-exist" in the boat.

My summary does not do this story justice. Like I said, this isn't my normal genre of movie, but it held my attention and interest all the way through. I would highly recommend watching -- or even reading -- The Life of Pi. There is a reason it gets such good reviews.
Even if you don't care for the intricate plot of this movie's intriguing story, it's a must-see as far as special effects are involved, especially if you're an animal lover.

The movie started a bit slow but once it moved from land to sea the spectacle began.  The fantastical visuals blurring the line between reality and delirium engrossed me and took me to another place.

The ending, leaving the viewer to ponder what actually happened was a nice surprise.  You choose, and then...

Ultimately, everyone will pass the buck and the consumer will NOT watch the film. :-(

I will update this 'review' when somebody tells me why Life of Pi will NOT play on my player when every other Blu-ray disc I've rented or own plays perfectly.

We watched this last night for the first time without having read the book or any reviews so this review is strictly on the movie itself. This is a powerful and effective movie which grabs you by the shoulders and gives you a good long shake. It doesn't let go even after the movie is over as one's mind speculates on the alternative stories and considers which one to be really true.

Visually the movie is graphic and powerful and has a variety of strong images mixed with beauty and wonder; if you watch it late at night you may have trouble sleeping. I've found it hard to put the images and thoughts of the movie behind me as scenes from the movie keep returning to my mind.

I recommend you approach this movie with caution as it is a force with which to be reckoned and can imbed itself in your memories.

I HATE this movie! NO SPOILERS! Notice that I didn't use the past tense, hated, but the present tense, hate. My loathing of this film is an active and ongoing thing. Life of Pi starts off nicely enough with an interesting story that you think is going in one direction and then whip lashes you in another... Fair enough I suppose, I don't mind being surprised. What offended me the most was the extreme violence depicted in the film. Had I lived back in the days of the Roman Empire, I would NOT have been front row center when they brought the animals out for slaughter. Yet, for the entire second half of the movie, we are asked to sit and watch the surviving animals from a shipwreck kill and eat one another in a tiny lifeboat. If you've seen the film you'll know that it's all OK because of the twist ending. I found the computer generated imagery to be sadly lacking and the entire movie feels like a sick trick that is played on the viewer. I HATE THIS MOVIE!

Having yet to read the book, I watched the film mainly as an illuminator for the novel, which I am now eager to start. I can only say that LIFE of PI is like no other film that I have ever seen. I expected it to be good but also feared it might have some of those fluffy "Oh, aren't I deep and brilliant?!" qualities. My fears proved baseless. LIFE of PI incorporates mystical and philosophical themes very well without detracting from its engaging, hypnotic storyline. It's also touching and poignant without being the least bit sentimental. Despite a few choppy bits, there isn't a seriously dull moment here. Suraj Sharma/Irrfan Khan play the protagonist quite convincingly, but it's the fine cinematography that really makes this film. Absolutely stunning views of the ocean and its life and, of course, Richard Parker the tiger and various other animals.

Ang Lee rocks.
The remarkable Taiwanese director adds the crown jewel in an already lifetime-hall-of-fame-worthy arsenal of brilliant films (Crouching Tiger, The Ice Storm, the Wedding Banquet, Eat Drink Man Woman, Sense and Sensibility, Brokeback Mountain...I mean, really....what can Ang Lee NOT do?).  No other living director - and very few ever - comes close to the vision Lee delivers with Life of Pi.  From the indelible images of animals in a zoo that flood our field of vision over the opening credits to its final moments in a questionable raft riding rough pounding seas, the maestro creates a singular unified story for the ages...and all ages too.  Hard to imagine as a novel I never read, the book was not expected to yield such a bounty of sheer beauty and natural punch, but holy cow, it does!  Its a blockbuster And then some.  Even on DVD.  Pi is the sort of film that should be on permanent display once a week at least at a theater near you.

Though I'd give this film 4 and 1/2 stars due to a few very minor quibbles with pacing, I'm happy to give it 5 well-deserved stars on Amazon because it is such a relief to see a big movie of this caliber of quality and craftsmanship in 2013. Yes, there are still some fine movies being made (even some of the "tent-pole" blockbusters are satisfying) but 'Life of Pi' is as rewarding and, in its own way, as awe-inspiring as any of the current epic releases helmed by bigger budgets and bigger names. Under genius Ang Lee's impeccable direction the uplifting and absolutely heart-breaking tale of Pi and Richard Parker is brought to spectacular CGI "life" with an added and unmistakable dose of dignified Humanity so lacking today, not only in our movies but across our culture. The film is essentially a parable, in my opinion, about the perception of truth and how the human spirit creates magic out of unspeakable tragedy in the attempt to draw meaning and find redemption where there is little of either to be found. Is it the story of a young Indian boy adrift in a lifeboat on the ocean for 227 days with a Bengal tiger as his simultaneous enemy and companion? That, dear moviegoer or movie-watcher, is for YOU to decide. The exhilarating thing about 'Life of Pi' is that you will be amazed by it, and you will find yourself thinking about it. Most truly. Kudos to Ang Lee and everyone involved with the meticulous and admirable execution of this very special film experience. For those who first warmed to the tale via the  book by Yann Martel, rest assured that the spirit of that classic work is painstakingly preserved and adapted with humility and no small amount of splendor. A feast for the eyes, the senses and, especially, for the heart. Adults will hold this film dear, but if you have kids over age 9 (or maybe 12) get them to watch it with you. I have a feeling they will never forget it. It's actually comforting to know that films this lavish and yet so spiritually pure are still being green-lighted by the deservedly beleaguered Big Hollywood Machine. Hope springs eternal, I guess.

The movie and story was not at all what I expected.  It had a "Christian" undertone which was something about the movie I really enjoyed.  The special effects were spectacular and the story had a surprise ending which left you wondering about what really happened.

*** A minor spoiler (or two) here ***

Why 5 star and a title "not the movie I thought it would be?"  Because I went in with the notion that it was a relationship between a man and a tiger.  But as the story unfolded I was drawn into the movie.  Sure the scene(s) of animals suffering are hard, but this is reality.  What do you expect when a zebra falls 20+ feet - a broken leg!

Putting that aside, I was most surprised about the twist at the end of the movie (and I'm not giving anything away here).  All I can say is for those who didn't like the movie - I think you missed the core plot.  This movie resulted in a lengthy family discussion about the various symbolism and metaphors relating to life.

Imagine being isolated at sea for over 200 days in a similar situation and you might very well come out with a similar story.

So, I give it a 5 star rating because it was thought provoking, unexpected and had all of us engaged throughout the movie.

I'm about to stereotype myself ALL OVER this review.

I loved the book because I thought it demonstrated the positive aspects of religion and spirituality, without implying that anyone has any idea of what may or may not be happening beyond the observable world.  For me, the defining characteristic of Pi in the book was his unflinching sense of wonder and his unbridled determination to enjoy his life.  He enjoyed spirituality, so he explored it.  He enjoyed biology, so he explored it.  Importantly however, the tone of his narration emphasized the wonder of exploring many world views, rather than the superiority of any one world-view.

<rant>

I thought the movie really gutted that message.  Pi's atheist teacher from the book was completely removed, and his pursuit of Islam was downplayed to the point that many viewers probably didn't even notice it.  There were also many lines that I felt implied that he favored his new-found Christianity over the Hinduism of his childhood.  I only read the book once and watched the movie once, but I don't remember the book having these dramatic moments where Pi shouts "I surrender" to god (singular).  The movie wreaked to me of pandering to an American, WASP, Disney-loving audience who wanted to see this young brown savage find salvation in their god.

Yes, I was raised by American, WASP, Disney-loving people, and yes, who I am is very much a reaction to the negative aspects of that culture.  Take my review as you will.  I just think this movie is a disappointingly pale shadow of the book, and that it fails to capture even the spirit.

It also wasn't nearly as pretty as I'd expected from the reviews.  Richard Parker was impressive, as were most of the animals.  On the other hand, endless standing water has to be one of the easiest things to accomplish with CGI.  There were several moments when I suspected that the producers assumed the audience would be awe-struck by an endless expanse, and would need a moment to take in the scene.  Instead, I quickly became bored and began contemplating just how lazy the shot was, and how much better it could have been if they'd played with the perspective and/or field of view.  The movement of the boat in the waves during the storms was also completely unrealistic.  I've seen video games with better in-game physics.

I really thought that this movie was not worth the money or time.

</rant>

The plot moves along quite comfortably such that you don't feel rushed, neither do you feel bored. Before you know it, you are thoroughly caught up with the all the emotions of a shipwrecked Pi and his fierce Bengal tiger. I kept waiting for the tiger to become a beloved kitty cat, but it made the film interesting that he didn't (steel yourselves to be frightened by menacing growls & lunges). The movie has a twist at the end which I will not reveal. However once you watch the film in it's entirety, ask yourself the following questions: 1. "Which story do I believe?"  and 2. "Life of Pi" starts pleasantly, though is confusing.  It has the potential of being something quite thought provoking.  But, the thing quickly degrades into a hellish experience that will leave scarred memories, images that may well remain with the viewer for some time to come.

The mindless, idiotic fool that is the central character fumbles his way onto a life boat while intentionally wandering around on the deck of a ship that is struggling to stay afloat in typhoon conditions.  There are zoo animals confined on this ship, which are depicted as drowning below deck while the ship is slowly doing down.  People and animals suffer miserably, and you get to see it!

While everyone in your living room is begging you to please stop this miserable agony of a "movie"; you hold on hoping this garbage will improve eventually.  Then you get to see a hyena attack, and mutilate a zebra while the coward is standing in the lifeboat with a ten foot oar in his hands, just looking at the butchery with flies buzzing in & out of his cavernous pie-hole!

I slammed the stop button on the remote, and found myself desperately wishing I could grab that oar and do to the fool what he should have done to the hyena!

If you have children, or adults with sensitive demeanors in your family, be sure to avoid this ravishing torture at all costs!!

I found this tale a celibration of male in an uplifting and positive light seldom seen in films today. In fact, what I more commonly interpret in todays media is the complete opposite. Religion is also explored in a substantive and respectful light. What a concept. Finally, and the icing on the cake for me, was the dignity and respect paid to love, relationships, our deep connection with the animal kingdom, and in the end this man's Family. I don't hand out 5 stars easily, and rarely take the time to comment about films today, but the quality of this one in particular compelled me to do so. This is an instant classic in my library. Thank you to everyone involved in this inspiring production.

It's not often that I say that a movie is better than the book upon which it was based. But Life of Pi takes what I thought was a simple and unemotive book and creates a visually stunning and emotionally evocative movie.

As other reviews are noted, this movie is a visual masterpiece. Ang Lee injects the film with a bold and unique visual style. There's rarely a boring frame in this movie. There's always an interesting composition or lighting effect on the screen. That's no small achievement given that the story primarily takes place on a small boat with a single actor and a CGI tiger. I'm not often wowed by special effects, but some of the shots from underwater really were impressive.

I think Ang Lee and actor Suraj Sharma did a great job at drawing the emotional story out of this book. As I wrote in my review of the novel, the writing style is a bit dry and doesn't really evoke any emotions. However, Suraj Sharma's narration adds real depth to his character. He's not just telling viewers how he caught fish, but also conveying his grim determination to survive. I'm sure it's easier for live actors to convey emotion than it is for words on a page, but I found myself caring far more about the characters in the movie than I ever did in the book.

The movie is very faithful to the book. Perhaps surprisingly so. Ang Lee even kept the part in about Pi's conversion to Christianity and Islam. Again, I thought this was an improvement over the book. I thought the book spent far too much time in the beginning with random musings. The movie presents the same information but much more efficiently and beautifully.

Overall, I'd imagine this movie will please fans of the book, as well as any viewers who appreciate a good yarn. Even if you didn't care for the book, I strongly suggest you give this a try.

Second, the story line is good... has a lot to it, if you take the time to think about what the movie/story is all about.  One could argue, it's a classic man vs. nature story... or, it's a story about religious preferences... or, it's a life story of "letting go."  Or... that's the point - this story line works on a lot of levels.  So, if you enjoy movies that make you think, you'll probably find this entertaining and worthwhile.

Beautiful, ambiguous, funny. A story about several levels of  suffering, and the saving graces of  spunk, kindness, love, metaphor and imagination. Pi's father lets him witness the cruelty of the way things are --- nature red in tooth and claw. Pi's mother teaches him the gorgeousness of 'it all"  as embedded in the legends or stories of several of the the Hindu gods.  Pi is able to draw on these perspectives when stranded in a lifeboat at sea for many days.  As a student of Buddhism, I find some of the key concepts familiar..eg., to live involves suffering, I do not know enough about Hinduism to really make this comment, but Shiva's dance of  the wheel of  creation and destruction is 'in' this film.  The young actor makes Pi appealing, the adult actor is on target , and also I like it that he is not classically handsome. It is worth seeing a second time.  I have not read the book.

The parable used for communicating the greatness of believing in God is actually entertaining, which is why I am giving it 2 stars instead of 1. The animation used for the tiger and in several other scenes is breathtaking. But ultimately, I could not help but feel disappointed in the constant hammering of the idea of God.

Of course, it is pretty clear that there is a huge number of people out there who will not find any issues with the concept behind the movie, and as such will have a great time watching it. Since I have to acknowledge that if you are a believer, no matter of which religion, this is probably a very enjoyable film. I understand that. However, for those out there that are similar to me, do not believe in deities and have no interest in watching a film that argues for believing, then this is probably not a good option.
