On one level, this is an action-adventure film about a boy and a tiger stranded on a boat.  But if it's approached that way, the beginning and ending of the film seem hard to reconcile.  This film presents a question that gets to the heart of religious faith in a way that both the believer and the non-believer can appreciate.  It's about all religions, not just one.  Pi is serially attracted to several of the world's major faiths, but the unique dogma of each is not the appeal.  It's the idea of religion that is the subject of the film.  Soon after the scene is set, Pi endures a terrifying ordeal involving a tiger and a lifeboat.  When it's over, he tells his story to skeptical investigators.  What has really happened here?  By posing the question the way it does the film offers an answer that tries to unravel the nature of faith and the purpose of belief.  I can think of far less interesting ways of spending two hours than watching this beautiful, challenging and thought-provoking film.

The story of the making of the movie (in the blu-ray edition) is as fascinating as the movie itself.  Yes, it's (mostly) a digital tiger, but the technology simply does not reveal itself.  At all.  Side-by-side footage of the real tiger and the digital one are indistinguishable.  This is one case in which the work put into the making of the film is justified by the depth and beauty of the story.

The film Life of Pi follows the book very closely with the characters, the adventures, and the author's imagination. Most CGI looked extremely life-like, and the picture technicalities displayed the beauty of our earth as well as the beauty of man's creativity.
The disturbing part, however, remains the story and the theme. Self-proclaimed to "help you believe in God," Life of Pi shows you what modern adaptations to religion do: reduce it to a feel-good, insubstantial putty. You may get warm fuzzies from the intention of the film, yet you will be left with no concrete idea as to why you are feeling said fuzzies upon further analysis.
For me, the story frames religion as an extra force pushing to destroy you, which paradoxically keeps you alive through its trials--in essence, unnecessary work that serves to maintain your sanity and survival. Religion as voracious tiger, island, or--in the book--carnivorous blind man? Some people perhaps subscribe to religion as a necessary evil, though I find that answer untrue and unenlightened.
The movie turns into a dark, dragging depression with anecdotes to flash a smile on the viewer's face to keep him/her watching. Overall, the movie extended longer than the book and convinced me that I'd rather drown than consume Yann Martel's religious theory.

This is a movie that needs to be seen more than once, especially after the end, because (at least for me), a lot of questions popped up regarding timing/emergence of the animals. I would have preferred to have watched it again in a few hours, but because of the licensing, only 24 hours is allowed before being deleted from your devices, so with my schedule, able to watch only part of it again.

It had depth and originality, providing the audience with stories of life-changing and soul-making significance.  Would someone who likes "only action" movies with lots of guns and cars like it? Probably not. But read the summary and watch the trailer, and if it piques your interest, I'd definitely recommend that you watch it.

And if you're into the deeper mysteries of life, death, family, suffering, survival and liberation, the concepts of illusion,truth, perception and wisdom, you'd like this. Add to it the beautiful cinematography and you may be lost in its beauty as I was, mulling over the meanings of this and that with my friend for hours afterwards. I would buy it for $15  but not for $25. (The 25$ standard for me is industry-changing, movement-causing, classic-in-the-making movies - Shawshank Redemption, Matrix, Star Wars)

If you do order it, try to drop the hype you've heard from your mind, including this review - you may not like it after all. I've noticed that when people say a movie is great so much, and then I see it, I am usually disappointed.  Release your expectations for a better movie experience. The behavior of the tiger, Richard Parker, was not believable, specifically when he inextricably stayed under the canvas for so long.  Also, his inability to claw his way onto the canvas after Pi did not seem realistic.  Why did not Pi succumb to sunburn after days of exposure?  How Pi and Richard Parker survived with so little water was not adequately explained.
We thought that far too much time was spent on the lifeboat scenes for no purpose.  On the other hand, the last 10 minutes or so of the movie really tied the loose ends together and got our attention.

If only it were possible to rate LIFE OF PI as a 10-stars video, based on the following:
* Plot--This story is as magical as the fairy tales that fascinated us as children
* Characters-- Despite their foreignness (to us) as Indians, they have universal appeal as a family of four embarking on a life-changing journey.  The father is strict, knowing that he must teach his sons life's lessons in order to survive.  The mother's compassionate, yet practical.  The older son is more like the father; not so vulnerable to life's travails.  Younger son, Pi, is soulful and his classmates' bullying has helped strengthen his character and his ability to overcome adversity by using his clever intelligence.
* Dialogue--Conversations are believable and flow alongside the narration.  While the characters have Indian accents, it is easy to understand what they are saying.
* Acting--It is amazing how well the main protagonist, Pi, portrays his role.  It is his first professional acting and his performance is exceptionally good.  Each actor has fulfilled his/her role admirably.
* Direction--Ang Lee is known for exploring complex themes.  His adaptation of the novel was outstanding.  He won the Best Director Oscar at the 85th Academy Awards, pitted against the renowned Steven Spielberg.
* Sequencing--There are no disjointed cuts in this movie.  With so many locales and scenes, it is almost expected to be choppy in places.  The movie segues seamlessly from one moment to the next.
* Sets--Filming is done in India, Canada, on a ship, at sea, a tiny island, and in a hospital room.  The vast majority of it is at sea on a small lifeboat and flimsy raft.  The smallest details are included in each one, adding depth to their locales.
* Visual Effects--Done with CGI, it is impossible to discern if the animals are real or digitally portrayed.  Staring into the tiger's eyes is frightening and at times, breathtaking, as Richard Parker's (the tiger's) face assumes almost human emotions.
* Color--Simply spectacular!  We watched this on a Samsung TV, giving us an enormous spectrum of color in many shades. Compared to watching other movies and regular programming, the hues of this film were superior to anything else we have seen, except at movie theaters.
* Technology--Filmed in HD and 3D, viewers get as realistic a feeling of actually `being there' as possible.  Clarity overall was excellent and made the nighttime sea life and storm scenes `pop'.  The same is true for the island locale.  While we do not have 3D, we think those very scenes and locales must do a magnificent job of enhancing the experience.

If you usually watch a movie more than once, then you can count on enjoying LIFE OF PI many times.

Life of Pi is a story of Pi Patel, the son of a zookeeper, who is the sole human survivor of a  violent shipwreck. We see his struggle for survival aboard a 26 foot boat with a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker who is initially a threat to Pi's life, but ultimately saves his life.

This movie certainly did the book justice for me. A visual feast for the eyes, the film lives up to the imagery described in the novel. I did not see the movie when it came out in the theatres, but I can imagine how even more beautiful it must have been. It was as if someone took the color on my TV screen and turned it up to number 12.

One such beautiful scene is when suddenly at night, Pi is surrounded by glowing jellyfish which light up the night; meanwhile, a whale rises and soars out from underneath the water. It is one of the most visually impressive scenes I have ever seen and Ang Lee's visual effects team is deserving of the Oscar.

Many scenes I was looking forward to being in the movie were actually in the film. One is the scene where Pi writes his name on the board at the start of each class to best make his name memorable to his classmates and teachers. Also true to the novel, we also see the alternate ending Pi gives to the detectives.

In terms of differences, while the movie is very close to the storyline novel, the book is much more in depth. The scenes with Pi's religious contemplation is much more involved as well as his survival on the boat. On the contrary, the scene when the boat is caught up in the storm and about to sink is actually more intense than that scene in the book itself.

Another difference to note is that the movie is not as graphic as some scenes in the book. With scenes of some of the animals attacking and killing each other on the boat, as well as the "interesting" food choices Pi is forced to make trying to survive, I expected a little more gore...although I cannot say I am disappointed to be spared seeing such moments, especially since I watched it with my four year old son! I suppose in order to appeal to children and maintain a PG-13 rating, these graphic elements could not be included.

My verdict is to see watch this movie! I would have enjoyed Lee's Life of Pi even more had I experienced the visual effects on the big screen. This is definitely an enjoyable film, even to those who adore the book.

Without giving the movie away, all I can say is that the ending was very disappointing! If the acting, dialogue and plot other than the main tiger scenes were developed even slightly, then I may have at least enjoyed the movie as a whole. Positives: the "fantasy-impressionist-style" cinematography at see was spectacular, and some of the tiger scenes almost made me hold my breath, but not enough to save the entire message of the movie, which is important for me. I'm 54, have seen hundreds of movies from classics to foreign to documentary, have been an avid reader since the age of 9, was an honors student through school, and majored in English. There is no way in my mind that this movie should have gotten the attention that it did.

The concept of this film is bizaare.
Hardly inspired but certainly iconoclastic just for the sake of being so.
And then submitting two possible interpretations at the very end - what does that add?
It begins with an odd premise in the first place - a vegetarian family in India that runs a private zoo full of carnivorous animals who moves it to Canada on a ship - well it's a new first at least.

It's implausible from the beginning but succeeds thereafter as an involving fantasy with appealing visuals.
The tacked on alternative ending serves little purpose but I guess does serve to bring it all down to reality in a certain way.
An oddity is this film's obsession with vegetarianism vs. meat eating.
From the Buddhist ship travellers assuring the Indian family that the gravy is ok for a vegetarian (even though it might have meat in it???) , to the father showing the son the violence of the tiger as it attacks a helpless young goat, to the implied gorging of the tiger on the orangutan, zebra and hyena, to the vegetarian family with carnivores to an island of more meerkats per sq. foot than ever seen before providing more flesh for the tiger.......see what I mean?
The whole thing is nonsensical.  Or maybe it just requires more suspension of belief than the usual movie fantasy.
Also I understand why he is called Pi, but what does that have to do with anything else in the story?
Including his ability to memorize and calculate incredible numbers of digits for the value of pi?

Even though there never was a moment when I thought "Gee why didn't I think of that" I give it 4 stars anyway for the wtf factor alone.

There are scenes I would not want a little one to view. The movie moves slowly, so you have to be in the mood for that and fantasy thoughts mixed into real... I am surprised it won Academy awards... but the scenes are beautiful.

LIFE OF PI is quite simply a visual feast of spectacle.  From the Indian locations of Pondicherry in the past, to the sequences taking place at sea, a quite wonderful evocation of an uninhabited island where the plants are predatory, to the final sequence taking place in sunlit suburbia in Canada, the film is full of memorable images.  The moments involving the animals - especially Richard Parker the tiger - are equally memorable; if they have been created using CGI, they certainly did not seem so.  Director Ang Lee has a wonderful way of suggesting the animal's predatory nature, yet at the same time its straightforwardness (unlike the human characters).  At the same time, I have to admit that the plot of LIFE OF PI is slight, to say the least: one can understand the central character's desire to discover himself and his relationship to God, but the progress of moving towards self-awareness is sometimes a slow one.  The film drags on occasions; one wishes that more character-conflict had been introduced, especially involving Grard Depardieu, who has a memorable cameo as an obstreperous ship's cook.

If Frank Darabont's The Shawshank Redemption, James Cameron's Titanic, and Alfred Hitchcock's Lifeboat made you believe in the power of story, then so shall Ang Lee's Life of Pi by way of Yann Martel's book of the same title. Like Shawshank Redemption, the protagonist undergoes physical, mental, and emotional damage that will either kill him or make him stronger although transformed. Like Titanic, a ship goes down and carries away family, safety, and security upon its descent. Like Lifeboat, an unusual mix of characters share tight, claustrophobic, treacherous quarters in a bid to survive at sea. Life of Pi is a beautiful story well-matched with breathtaking cinematography, visual effects, and sound design. Based upon the strength of these separate elements operating together in excellence, Ang Lee won Best Director.

Truly fantastic is the powerful allegorical revelation of God in science based upon two interpretations of horrific, life-changing tragedies in the world of the protagonist a teenage boy. A storm at sea throws Pi either into the hands of God, or Mother Nature, or as Pi would have it--both. Driven to his physical, mental, and emotional limits while adrift for 227 days in the Pacific Ocean, Pi addresses the strains on his capacities by adapting to his horrific reality via spiritual, religious, scientific means, or perhaps cognitive dissonance.

Some may view Pi's interpretations of his reality as opposite and therefore impossible. Others may view Pi's interpretations as complementary, and entirely reasonable. One step further and the viewer may even choose to accept the concept of God as the creator of all science and all scientific laws, God as the creator of evolution. Two steps further and the viewer may understand that logic and reason remain entirely compatible with religion and spiritualism. After two viewings, the only surprise that remains with Life of Pi is that it did not win the award for adapted screenplay.

His father thought it was foolish. The story continues and eventually, he discovers Richard, the Bengal tiger, and he is taught a lesson about what the animal really is. I don't think he learned anything from that lesson, and I don't think he ever does. The story kept moving and eventually went to the ship sinking and how Pi came to survive with the tiger.

Pi is a precocious Indian boy from Pondicherry, India.  His family owns a zoo.  In that zoo is a Bengal Tiger named Richard Parker.  Pi is also a spiritual child, rebelling against his rationalist "New India" father.  In his spiritual journey, Pi melds Christianity, Islam and Hinduism in his effort to find and love God.  A cynic might interpret this as a touchy-feely globalist literary prop to make the movie more likeable to a broad global audience whose members are actually locked in post-enlightenment zeitgeist of religious war and tension.  That same cynic might also add that the true god of Corporate Globalism is a one-out-of-three unholy trinity of Migrants, Mammon, & Moloch.

The political situation shifts in India and Pi and his family sell the zoo and transport the animals on a Japanese freighter for Canada.  On the ship they meet a rude French cook, a kind-hearted Japanese sailor and look after their animals.  One night there is a terrible storm and the freighter sinks, Pi is the only human survivor.  On the lifeboat, which is half covered by canvas, is an injured zebra, an female orangutan who has lost her baby to the sea, and a vicious hyena.  As the shipwrecked zoo progress on their journey, the hyena kills the zebra, than the orangutan, and then suddenly , Richard Parker, the Bengal Tiger leaps from under the canvas, killing the hyena.  Pi is then alone, with a vicious tiger.  Pi must tame the great cat and use his wits to help them both survive.

In an epic of surreal filmography Pi and Richard Parker drift across the Pacific, during one storm Pi sees Almighty Providence, when he tries to show the sight to Richard Parker, the tiger is seized with fear and must duck under the canvas.  In a delirium, Pi and Richard Parker wash up on a strange island-a garden of plenty by day but death by night.  Eventually, Pi washes up on a beach in tropical Mexico, and the tiger returns to the to jungle without looking back. Pi is then rescued by natives.

At this point, the viewer is left with an unsettled feeling.  Pi's more important journey with God is soul-less, globalist nonsense, his reconciliation is nowhere near as believable as Lieutenant Dan's Jacob-like wrestling with God while tied to the mast of a shrimp boat during Hurricane Camille.

However cynicism drops away and the entire meaning of the movie changes in retrospect with a subtle plot twist. Pi speaks to some Japanese officials in a Mexican hospital.  They are investigating the shipwreck as part of an insurance claim.  They don't believe his story.  He tells a different story-one of a dying, kind-hearted sailor, a resourceful and Darwinian French cook, and his scared mother in a lifeboat.  This story is darker, more emotionally taxing, and involves murder and cannibalism.  Without letting on which story is true, Pi mentions that the tiger Richard Parker was much like his Id, his will to survive, his inner-evil.  During the storm, when Pi sees The Almighty, Richard Parker can only tremble in terror.  This, second story takes the movie to a higher level.  It is a story that sticks in the mind, causing one to think backwards about the nuanced, subtle details in the story.  A viewer then picks at the suddenly real, suddenly rich, and suddenly colorful spiritual symbolism.

Aside from the fact that the movie's graphics are superb, the story within the story (or was it an enveloping story), underscores how the human brain interprets the close environment and applies the necessary components to make the story about the environment palatable. A great deal of research (see Michael Gazzaniga's works), has gone into the ability to understand why the brain sees such illusory components in order to make sense of the real world. This story speaks volumes about the resilience of our brain. Thank you evolution.

I finally got around to watching Life of Pi. I was less than impressed.

Sure, it was full of great visuals. Amazing visuals, even, but those don't make the story. [It's the same reason I could never follow a crappy story in a comic book just because it had good art (Spawn).] The story in Pi was very much lacking. The only reason it gets such a "wow, that was so deep" response is that it's one of those stories (the movie for sure and probably the book (though I haven't read the book)) that people can't figure out. Rather than say "I don't understand," they instead say, "that's so deep." Especially the critics, who can never just admit that something doesn't make any sense. Vague symbolism is always a sure way to baffle the critics into saying something is great. [One of my college professors was the same way. The sure way to getting an "A" from him on a paper was to write something beyond his understanding or deliberately vague enough that it seemed beyond his understanding. Rather than say "I don't know what you're saying here" or "This doesn't make any sense," he'd just put an "A" on it.]

However, the biggest problem with that aspect of the movie is that there is a message in there, revealed twice during the movie but obfuscated rather than just stated plainly: believing a lie is better than believing nothing. Or, as it's put forth at the end, "It's better to believe a beautiful lie rather than an ugly truth." That's a sorry message to be delivering and one I just can't get behind. No matter how pretty the package it's wrapped in, and Pi is a pretty package with beautiful bows and ribbons. It's not enough to disguise the ugly truth of the movie, though. Well, maybe, actually, it is. For most people.

The other big issue I have with the movie is that I hate (I mean I absolutely can not stand) getting to the end of a story just to find out that it didn't happen. [I mentioned this same thing in my review of Looper.] Don't waste my time with a story about a story that didn't happen. Don't have it turn out to be a dream. Don't have it turn out to be a time loop that gets closed off so that none of it happened. Don't have it turn out to be a hallucination to cover up something that the character can't handle. You've wasted my time at that point.

And, in Life of Pi, it reduces the only interesting part of the movie to the 30-40 minutes that happen before the storm. Then it's over. And that was hardly a story and one in which nothing really happened other than that someone survived a horrible stranding at sea.

And, sure, you can get all wrapped up in discussions about whether the tiger was God or what the heck was that island supposed to be, anyway, or whether he just made up the story he told the insurance people about the cook just so that they would have something they could grasp, but none of it matters. It doesn't matter because of the statement, "Which is the better story, and wouldn't you rather believe that thing than believe the truth?"

So, yeah, sure, Pi was pretty. It deserved the awards it got for those aspects of the movie, but it certainly wasn't a "best directed" movie. It was a hardly directed movie. I'm glad I watched it; I even kind of wish I'd seen it on the big screen just for some of the scenes on the ocean; but I don't think it was a great movie. It might look all deep when looking down on it, but, if you put your feet in, you'll find it's just a wading pool.
I know this is a good movie but I have not watched it yet. Hope to do so in the near future.
The Life of Pi is funny, entertaining, and adventurous. The boy keeps an excellent attitude in difficult circumstances. He is a bit confused when it comes to religions.

After all the hoopla and awards, we sat down to watch this movie at home. Now I'll admit the cinematography and the 3 D effects on a movie theater screen probably were spectacular, not so much on my home tv. Since it is most times difficult to understand dialogue with Indian, English and Australian accents; we always use the close captioning feature. Since this is not a feature you get in the theater we could actually understand the dialogue. When you can understand the dialogue and without the special effects , we found this movie boring and unbeleivable with an ending that we laughed at.
Interesting story line. I enjoyed the fact that how they leave you at the end questioning the reality of his tale. Wonderful scenery!!
This film is a great life story. Adventures and well acted. Exciting and thought prevoking. I have watched this film several times.

the wife and I sat down to watch this after all the awards season hubbub, and we must say that we agree. In a time where movies seem to be trending behind a "dark & dreary" i.e. (let's redo snow white, with a dark edge to it!, let's redo Batman, again, and make him EVEN DARKER) this movie was a welcome departure from that recent trend. This story very much took a dark subject matter and paints it in a warm vibrant light, although the story itself is very dramatic, the way the story is chosen to be told, works wonders. Will definitely watch this movie again.

One of the most engrossing cinematic productions I've seen in some time. I would recommend this to others at any time. So glad I watched this movie. Will probably end up purchasing this beautiful, spell binding films of the year.

Life of Pi was a bad movie because our family had to stop watching it when the animals were killed on the life boat. This film should be rated PG 13 because it is so sad. Most young viewers of this movie will be disturbed.
This movie makes you think. A little slow to start but picks up later. Good viewing for a wet afternoon,
I purchased this movie and we loved it.  I bought it from Amazon so that I could show it to the residents at a retirement community where I work,  they loved it.
This is a beautiful movie that bears watching repeatedly in order to continue receiving it's message.  I strongly recommend it.

An entertaining movie that keeps the viewer wondering how the film makers accomplished the shot.  I did find the animation to occasionally become too unbelievable.  I do recommend the movie as a "must see".

The story was unusual. The photography was magnificiant. I enjoyed the French dialogue
How does one train  a tiger  like
 that?

The story carries meaning on mutliple levels from learning how to let go of the ones we love, to facing our fears and deciphering the realities in our lives versus the smoke screens. In addition it is a visually stunning film with bright colors and contrasts.

From the trailers, I thought The Life of Pi would be uplifting, with elements of an adventure story.  Instead, it was a brutal lesson of survival in the animal kingdom.  I don't choose to watch those shows where the poor antelope is ripped to shreds by its predator.  I had no idea that that's what I'd be subjected to in this movie.  And to what end?  What uplifting, or even edifying, conclusion can we reach?  Oh yes - animals are animals.  Survival of the fittest.  A tiger may be trained, but he'll never love you or be your pet.  This is not entertainment, in my book.  The 2 stars are for the excellent acting and animation.  Everything else was just upsetting and depressing.
Even better than the reviews and awards intimated. great special effects and drama for two most unlikely shipmates who strive to survive.

Ang Lee's latest film Life of Pi is a visually stunning and breathtaking experience. It is one of the few films that, in my opinion, is actually better suited for 3D than boring ol' 2D, and is perfect to experience in the movie theater rather than Netflixing in a couple months.

Pi is so impressive because it is consistently entertaining and surprising for two or so hours, surprising for a plot that doesn't have much action. It does follow a pretty standard Hero's Journey format, with some pretty sad (but not tear-jerking) moments. By the end, it becomes clear that almost every scene is necessary (save the love story that goes nowhere). Plus, it borrows from Big Fish in that much of what REALLY happened is left open to interpretation, and I like to see that in big-budget movies. It is far too infrequent that we get films that generate engaging discussion among audiences, and I am happy that Life of Pi gives us that opportunity.

The film's strongest suit, as you've no doubt heard, is its visual effects. The best effects, in my opinion, are always those which blur the line between what is real (physical) and what is not (CGI), and Life of Pi provides consistently jaw-dropping and convincing images that are hard to forget. The camera work is exceptional as well, with non-traditional shots and transitions. Some of the most memorable are bird's-eye shots, overlooking the protagonist Pi and the tiger Richard Parker floating in the sea, at a perfect 90-degree angle.

As much of a visual and intellectual treat as Life of Pi is, it is hard for me to imagine Academy members and audiences regarding it as the best film (not just one of the best films) of 2012. I absolutely liked it, hands down - but in a year with emotional powerhouses like Silver Linings Playbook, Brave, and many other movies that left a stronger impression on me, it is really a far cry from Best Picture 2012.

This was an excellent book and Ang did a great job capturing that in this film adaptation. It is clear in the movie that faith does not have to be viewed strictly on religious terms; spirituality and faith transcend any particular religion. Bonus: the CGI is amazing!

This was not quite what I was expecting from the trailers we saw. I enjoyed it as I got deeper into it and it opens up a spiritual
meaning I wasn't expecting.

I felt that this movie explains a major difference in atheists and religious people. To live life on logic alone, and what's on the surface is what you get, or live by blind faith, and hope for something possibly more beautiful. It boils down to preference. Have you ever had a religious argument that dragged on and went no where? Well, I guess you'd get similar results trying to tell a vanilla ice cream fan that chocolate is better.

This is an absolutely amazing movie on many fronts: visual effects; engaging story; unbelievable animal behavior sequences, & simply fantastic photography. I compare it to Avatar as far as being in a class by itself. There has Never been anything on the screen quite like this movie, and once seen--never to be forgotten

Stock up on your snacks before you watch this movie:  you won't want to miss a second.  A young Indian boy finds himself adrift on a lifeboat, crossing the Pacific Ocean with a tiger for "company".  The two establish unenforceable rules, but batter winds, storms,and a freaky island.  I'm not one to give away plots.  Just see this movie over and over!
Great graphics, poor story line, and worse ending. One of those flicks where when it was over, I wanted my money back.
I like everything about this movie.  The plot, the storyline, the actors, and the cinematography all were amazing and put together to make a excellent movie.
Not something I would watch more than once or recommend to others.  I'll probably give it to my grandchildren who are 3 & 5

I felt the imaginative challenges of reading the novel were more entertaining than the CGI wizardry.  Maybe it's a generational thing, but these hybrid movies where I know actors are playing in front of a blue screen and a computer wizard is tweaking pixels somewhere else, I have a hard time getting engaged. "Because we can" is sometimes not a good enough reason to do something.  This example is well done, but in the end I have to ask, "So what?"
The concept of the movie didn't attract me.  everthing I thought I a movie to rent or go the theater, Ive always overlooked this one.  BIG MISTAKE.  I love this movie
The book was one of my favorite reads and I was sure I would be disappointed.....I wasn't.  I thought the movie was well done AND true to the book.

Saw it in the theater and the award-winning cinematography really loses a lot in the translation to the home screen. It's an interesting story. I don't like the the existential mind gravy offered at the end and felt tricked.  Still, the movie has so many wonderful qualities I had to give it 5 stars.
Good Movie, better book.  It's great to see films in this format. I enjoy viewing movies in this format. Good stuff
Yes, it was a beautiful movie to behold. The ending could disturb you, but that's up to you. I enjoyed it.

This movie is excellent for all ages and is especially excellent in 3D. The photography in this movie is phenominal. The movie was shipped to my house as advertised and was well packaged. Opening the package was easy. Everything about this experience was great. I love Amazon's service and recommend buying anything from Amazon, you will not be disappointed.

I was skeptical that the movie could begin to do justice to the book, but this is a phenomenal rendering. It is a visual delight and very true to both the story line and the mood of the book. Well worth a watch.
nice movie something a bit different from your typical adventure movies, had a nice plot as well as nice and beautiful scenes. I def. recommend it!

This is an amazing movie! A story of hardship. Of trials of mind, body and spirit. Of love, hate and fear. Of overcoming our worst fears and learning who we really are. Would you survive? A must see movie and it will change your life.
Enjoyed this movie and the visual was stunning. Good for ages 10 and up. Smaller children may not understand the theme. Small amount of violence in beginning.
The cinematography was phenomenal but the story was a bit immature, so this would be a great movie for kids.

it wasn't that bad of a movie and it was kinda entertaining but i was really turned off by how preachy it was and how religion based it was... if i had known it was going to harp on religion so much i wouldnt have watched it.

The movie version of Life of Pi is directed by Ang Lee and includes quite a lot of computer graphics. It looks good in 3D and is well acted. Suraj Sharma and Irrfan Khan deserve a special mention as the young and adult Pi. Gerard Depardieu plays a small but significant role. Adil Hussain and Tabu are excellent as Pi's parents. The screenplay is fairly true to the book, but there is a romance element that has obviously been added, Hollywood style, and is completely unnecessary. There is a scene in the ship's dining room which, while not in the book, obviously serves as a device to give background for the alternative story by introducing the sailor who breaks his leg, and the cook. I was sorry the scene with the priest, the imam and the pandit was omitted. While the CGI and 3D effects were brilliant, I felt the storm/sinking ship scenes asked the viewer to suspend disbelief a little too much: how did Pi manage to get back to the lifeboat from so far away in the high seas? I was glad I had recently reread the book so I was completely familiar with it, and I feel the movie kept the overall spirit and feel of the book. Would I watch it again? Definitely! Would I recommend seeing it in 3D? Absolutely!
Really enjoyed this movie and its ending......really leaves you thinking :) I choose to believe the story with the animals and his amazing bond with the tiger.
Wasn't sure we would like this movie but saw it advertised on TV. I'm really glad I purchased it. It was really good. My husband even liked it and he is an action movie buff
This was a surprise, not at all what I was expecting from the commercials but it was very interesting. I would not recomend it for children. I have watched it twice.

I had read the book years ago and the movie from my recollection does a good job of recreating the book.  I am sure its not as detailed but, I really enjoyed the movie.  The effects were great.  3d was good but, more so in increasing the depth as opposed to in your face effects.  Although there were some good in your face shots also.  Would definitely recommend but as one other viewer noted may not be for young eyes.

The Oscar's love of everything non-Christian is proven yet again.  What a bunch of bunk.  Trying to make India some surreal paradise in this fantasy really amazed me, since India has an 80% poverty rate that makes our poor in the United States look rich.  The story was nothing out of the ordinary and was mildly entertaining.
This is an excellent movie.  The acting is superb...from all the principal actors.  The story line is interesting...and their are many lessons to be learned from the movie.  Highly recommended!
I saw this movie in theaters in 3D and I really wanted to see it again. It was still just as good. It really is a long movie but the depth of the movie is great.

A wonderful story of a man lost at sea, his rescue, and how the experience changed his life. A must see movie. I don't want to give too many details, as I might spoil it for someone who wants to watch it.
A beautiful story with real spiritual significance. Gorgeous cinematography and nature enhancing special effects. I will watch again soon. word

It took Ang Lee 4 years to make this movie and it was a total waste of time.  Four years ago, Bollywood may have been hot but not by the time it was released.  This movie was not enjoyable in so many ways as the story was not credible and the special effects were a joke.  The dialogue was from a storybook and shallow in content.  Do not waste two hours of your life watching such a bad movie.
I was not sure what to expect, it's was a good movie overall, very real on life, not happy go lucky so don't expect that. Visuals were beautiful.
I loved this movie, a great movie for the whole family. I hope this helps all to watch movie. I loved it
Seller followed through with shipping time. Life of Pi was a touching movie. Great for families. Helps you appreciate family, nature, and religion. =)

I enjjoyed this film because it was a bit different .The only thing I didn't like was seeing all the animals drowning and then being killed by the tiger . Im an animal lover and any sort of animal suffering really upsets me. I know it wasn't real and that it was just hollywood but it still upsets me. Putting all that aside as It was only a very small part of the movie I found the movie unusual in its story line. I was disappointed at the end when the tiger didn't look back. I wanted to think that a kind of bond had developed between human and wild animal. I was thinking that was the way the story was developing. I was surprised by this movie as it didn't develop as I thought it would.

We were anxious to see this movie after all the hype that surrounded it. After watching it, why all the hype? This movie does deliver a question about humanity but it was too slow in delivering that message. I actually was watching the clock hoping it would end soon. Had I watched it alone, I probably would have stopped watching. The visuals were nice, but as some have said there were some discrepancies in those visuals, the goat would not have gone thru the bars. The ads for the movie made it seem like a good movie for the whole family. I disagree. To explain why we didn't like the movie, I would have to give details and if you want to watch it, no need to spoil it. I would not recommend giving up 2 hours of your precious time to see this. That is time you will never get back.
I loved the movie and the fact it came with a 3d disc,blue ray and regular disc. This is a great deal.
This was an amazing story, what imagination went into it.  Also seeing it in 3-D was an experience.  You do not have to go to the theater to see a beautiful 3-D movie, anymore, also.
What a great movie! Wonderful animal movie. Acting was good, the plot was great and the storyline was quite exciting. Watch this movie!

Superb! It kept me interested throughout the film. I cried a few times and laughed a lot The  scenes were gorgeous I only wish I could have viewed it in 3D.  If you are an animal lover like me, beware,  as there are some very sad parts .I could not watch. LOL  It was a wonderful story and much easier to follow then the book was.

After reading the book I watched the movie. Although the movie was very well done, it is simply not possible to do the whole story in a 2 hour movie.  If you liked the movie then you must read the book to read understand Pi's fantastic adventure.

I was so disapointed. Every time a character moved or anything else for that matter it blured badly. I had the same problem with Ice Age Continental Drift and Darkest Hour. I have a LG Cinema style 3D tv with an LG 3D blueray player. I have a top dollar high speed HDMI cable running between the two. I don't have this problem with the dozens of other 3D movies I own and no problems with my DirecTV 3D programing either. Does anyone else have this problem? I can't be the only one.
I found this film interesting, although implausible. It did, however, keep my interest from start to finish and I did not fall asleep if only for a few minutes.
This is such a fun movie for everyone!  The graphics are incredible and the movie is inspiring.  I recommend it.
I enjoyed this movie.  Story was interesting, effects were good.  It appealed to my grandaughters as well as my husband.
This movie was so well made! I just loved it! I went out a bought it right away! You won't be disappointed with this movie.

Great story. I read the book several years ago and had forgotten how engaging, imaginative and touching the story is. The movie does justice to the story. And the cinematography is absolutely stunning.
The story is good, but it could have been told I mush less time. It is slow at times so don't started it to late or you will fall asleep.
My nearly 10 year old and I watched this together and he was engulfed in the story.  A nice change of pace from the normal good vs. evil he is drawn to.
This movie was very interesting. Interesting but not proable. Some scenes were  very good.  But I found it not crediable. Great picture s of the different animals....
A great story of human happiness and pain narrated by the protagonist when everything has passed and the time has brought wit and wisdom to the survivor.
Great movie and really makes you think about your life and faith. The tiger was a huge role in the movie which of course i loved.
Wow, really cool special effects and very interesting story line.  I loved this movie and would recommend it for anyone to watch.  Adults and kids.
It was different than I expected but I still enjoyed Kids would like it. I would not consider buying this movie..

I was expecting more. All of the religious references are detracting. And it seemed there was a desperation in trying to build a story around a spectacular event. The visuals are stunning, of course and there are some very tense and emotional moments. But as a whole, it doesn't quite work.
It's a great movie that really makes you think at the end. It also was really fun to watch in 3d.
I enjoy watching this movie. Started out slow but the pace pick up.  The 3D dvd was outstanding.  I would recommend it!
Life of Pi conveys a deeply heartfelt story with absolutely unforgettable imagery. I am also very pleased that proceeds from the sale of this item benefit a worthy cause.
Liked It very much. Read the book first and did not think the movie was going to be that good. Was pleasantly surprised.

Beautiful film, exceptionally well photographed and acted and animated. I chose it because of the buzz surrounding it, and I'd un-hesitatingly recommend it to everyone, young, middle aged, or old, male or female. It was excellent!

I did not know what to expect when I watched this movie. It was very different than anything I have seen for a long time. Beautiful cinematography, unique story. The end really got to me. I did like this movie, but I can't say that I would watch this one too often. Only for the fact that it is a little slow starting and it is kind of sad. Other than that, it was done beautifully.
Cinematography was excellent. It follows the book very well, It's a spiritual journey. Watch it! You know you are going to love it.
Pretty entertaining and visually appealing. The  movie was one of the more original I have seen in quite some time. I would recommend.
I am sorry to say I did not have a chance to see this movie as yet.  But the movie and case look very nice.  It was sent in a timely manner.
I found this very interesting and was riveted to the TV until it was over. It brought out some interesting "life" values, and was a story of great courage and ultimately, faith.

Not my favorite movie - but interesting to say the least. Hate that at the time it was only available by purchase instead of rental. I spent a lot of money to watch a movie once. Good idea if you plan to watch something numerous times though. Wish I had been given the option of viewing and then they would send a hard copy DVD when available with purchase.

This no Hollywood formula script.  You already know about the kid and the tiger but get ready to experience amazement that you've never experienced before.  Pi's fear will be your fear - absolutely no lie.  But Richard Parker steals the film.  Watching Richard Parker play his role is nothing short of miraculous!  He was ROBBED of his Academy Award, and I have seen the film more than six times and I still can't find his credit.

This film will bite you as you have never been bitten before.  It is a very rare and unusual story that is magically brought to life.  Get your treats, go to the bathroom, and shut off the phone before you start this film.

You will not be able to look away.
I rent it for the second time (I should buy it) for my friend to see it, I think it has so many messages that need to be heard... I really enjoyed :)

Its a good movie, but I had got the notion that it was to be about the tiger, not the guy. I also felt that Pi  was a hit and miss about his life. Also the ending was not as good as I thought it should of been, did the tiger live or die?

I saw this film prior to my purchase. I bought it for a friend because I thought she would enjoy it. She HATED it!!! It was too dark for her. Needless to say, I sent her some movies that I knew shed loved and asked her to pop Life of Pi in the mail because it's one of the few movies I would actually love to own.

The film created a few diversions from the book's plot early on, but for most part it stayed true to Martel's story line, capturing the voice of Pi with stunning clarity. Ang Lee's artistic liberties, showcasing nature in all of its glory, encapsulated the overall interconnectedness of all life on this planet with broad brush strokes. Overall, LIFE of PI was definitely a great film.
Saw it in the theater, and purchased this for my parents. They loved it!! Would buy again in a heartbeat!

This movie had all the visual stimulation Hollywood loves to wow with and the plot was very similar to the book, but I can't help but feel there was something missing.
I was very impressed with the novel. So impressed, that when I found out a movie was being made, I was very excited to view it. However, it seemed that the focus was on main points not necessarily the same sort of focus the book portrayed. I may be more critical just because this is the way I interpreted the book, and to see the movie from such a different interpretation may have been where the disappointment stemmed from, but nevertheless I still finished the movie with an opinion that "nice, but if never watch that again." Feeling.
Love the story of this film and how it weaves present day with the past. Excellent special affects and life lesson storyline.
This was one of those rare times that a movie is actually as good as the book.  I would watch this again.
Very nice but like Peter Jackson's flix you get the feeling they were filling some space that didn't need to be.

For those who've read the novel, it's not the same -- but then again, when is it?  However, the movie is it's own medium, and recreates the experience viscerally, and I recommend you see it. For those who have not read the book, the movie is a must-see. You will not be disappointed with its journey and the metaphors are just as Biblical as they are literary.
Life of Pi was an unexpected delight.  I was expecting a kid movie but it definitely was not just for the younger set. I was wowed!!!!

My fourth grade students are fascinated by this movie...I am heavily front loading plot, vocabulary etc. for them this first time as we go but plan to use it next year with lesson plans I might be able to find on the web.  It is chock full of  action and, of course, the animals are breathtaking...love it and so do the kids!
To me it was boring, but again, many of my friends, loved it.. So do not judge the movie by my opinion, watch the trailer and make your own mind.
The cinematography is breathtaking and the film is very true to the book - a rarity in the book to film transition. Thoroughly enjoyable.

Beautiful movie. Husband wanted to watch this and I was only a little interested. The movie started and I was hooked. We sat on the couch on a Saturday afternoon watching this and we both loved it so much.
We immediately looked up to see if this was a true story or anything like that. We also picked up the book.

It was a beautiful movie, the colors, the cinematography. It was breathtaking. I was so stunned by the explanation at the end, I wanted to know what was real and what wasn't. I highly recommend this movie.

Good review of India.

Very boring, unimaginable story. I was surprised to hear that it got nominated for awards. I would pass!
We enjoyed this film. It was interesting and spell-binding at times. A bit sad but well worth the purchase. I think you will enjoy it.

A friend had seen this in the theatre and encouraged me to have a look.  So, when it came out on download, I thought about it.  Weeks later I decided on a slow day to watch it and it actually was amazingly entertaining.  It's a great story and having lost my Mother at a relatively young age, I could relate to the main character in many ways.  If you've been on the fence with this one but you like movies that surprise you a bit and have a really great message, you might want to give this one a chance...

Gives one something to think about when it comes to being stranded.  Who or what would you rather be stranded with.
Great plot and imagination.

Although this is an Ang Lee movie, which in itself is a type of guarantee, I wasn't too sure about watching this movie  a boy and a tiger on a boat??? But it turned out to be a must-see experience!!! The photography is magical!!!  The story itself is full of symbolism and impossible events  and the end, who cares which version is the real one? By that time you have already been part of a surreal fantasy that has hopefully enriched you.  Do not miss this movie!!!!

This is a good movie and is available in 3D, which is why we purchased.  Having read the reviews, we thought it would be awesome but, if purchasing in 3D for those effects, it is not as good as the deep sea 3D's available for $5 or so.  However, it is a good movie and am not sorry to have purchased, just don't even remember now - 2 months later - any particular 3D moments.  Avatar is really the best 3D movie so far, excepting the deep sea 3D's, which really jump out at you!
Ang Lee never disappoints, this is the best movie and not sure why it didn't win all the awards. Regardless it will stick with me forever.

I wondered if I would like the movie so I watched most of the preview. I was tempted to stop the video preview because it was too nightmarish. I don't like to see animals get hurt. I'm sure they didn't but it was horrible for me...so I don't want to see the movie.
DEFINITELY A MUST SEE MOVIE FOR EITHER YOUNG OR OLD.  TELLS TWO STORIES AT ONCE.  ONE FOR THE EYES AND ONE FOR THE SOUL.

After all the Academy Award hype, I wanted to see this film.  Parts of it were visually beautiful - even stunning.  I could not understand part of the dialogue, due to the Indian accents of some of the actors.  At times, I thought the plot dragged on abominably (but I was sick at the time and not very patient).  The ending was confusing and didn't seem to resolve anything.

But I loved the line "The story is now yours." Maybe I would do better to read the novel and discuss this with a book group.  It seems like there had to be more to it that I was not able to wrap my head around.

Honestly, I didn't have any intention on watching this movie because I seriously thought that it was a movie about a boy and his tiger.......well, i was wrong..It was so much more than that! The movie was great and I highly reccomend it to all to watch with the entire family.
This is a terrific movie.  I wondered how they would ever be able to convert this book into a movie and they did a phenomenal job, giving nothing away , keeping the ending a surprise.  Well done.

I missed this movie when it was in the theaters, so I was eager to see it as a rental.  I had heard the hype, and I was expecting to be blown away by this film.  On only rare occasions in my life have I been let down to this extent.

I borrowed the movie from my local library at the cost of one dollar. It wasn't worth it. The whole time I was watching it I was thinking, "What the hell is the point of this movie?? Is it going to get better any time soon??" I had to fight to stay awake. It was two hours of my life that went irretrievably down the drain.

I am absolutely at a loss to understand how any sane person could rate this movie anything higher than one star. What a profoundly ridiculous premise:  the kid is in a life boat adrift on the ocean along with a tiger, a zebra, an orangutan, and a hyena who take turns getting "lost" under a tarp that covers the front half of the lifeboat. They somehow magically appear at various times to provide material for each scene. One can almost hear the director out of sight saying, "Okay, cue the tiger!" The hyena and tiger pose an obvious threat to Pi's existence, but he easily could have just charged them when they were near the edge of the boat and...viola!...into the drink they go. No more threat. Oh wait, I forgot. That would make sense in his struggle for survival, but this is really an utterly pointless movie.

I thought it was too drawn out at the beginning trying to get my mind into it . The animal at the beginning did not make sense. The ending finally explained this. This Film is only suitable for a mature mind

This is an amazing movie.  If you think you know what will happen, you don't and something else happens.  The adolescent is wonderful -- almost as wonderful as The Tiger ("Richard Parker").  The kid grows up and his life goes on -- and The Tiger returns to the jungle.  If you can handle the shot where The Tiger eats a meercat on Meercat Island, you will love this movie.  I did -- I've ordered my own copy of the movie, and can't wait to watch it again.  And again.

Yeah...that's what I thought going into this, but I decided to give it a shot because Ang Lee has done some awesome stuff in the past and because several people I know saw it and said it was amazing.

THEY WERE RIGHT!

This is an incredible film that I would recommend to anyone of any age.  There is a lot to love.  The special effects are so lifelike that you forget that there is NO WAY they could have had the tiger and the boy on the same set.

You will not be disappointed with this film if you are a fan of a great story and great movies.
I was disappointed by the movie.  There was too much that was just not realistic and the way it was done was just, well, cheesy.  The adult actor paying Pi was very good.  Overall, not thrilled.

Ang Lee has a fine record for making unusual films, and from `Eat Drink Man Woman' through `Hulk' to `Brokeback Mountain' has proven to be the antithesis of a formulaic director. True to form, his film of Yann Martel's "un-filmable" book `Life of Pi' is a triumph of cinematography and storytelling. The underlying themes of God-evidenced-in-Nature and the victory of the human spirit in adversity are very well realised by Lee's narrative structure and editing, and the film is a feast for the eyes and the mind.

The story is told in first-person narrative with Pi as narrator, his character played by four different actors as he ages. The excellent young Suraj Sharma takes the lion's share (tiger's share?) as the 16-year old Pi in the film's main sequence when adrift on the Pacific with Bengal tiger Richard Parker following a shipwreck. Sharma (picked from 3,000 actors who auditioned for the part) delivers a convincing performance of fear, struggle, cool intelligence & courage, and gradually masters his hostile environment and terrible predicament, growing spiritually on the journey as he asserts dominance over the tiger so that they might both survive. Although for safety reasons the tiger and Sharma were filmed separately, you will absolutely believe in the terrifying visceral power of their face-to-face confrontations and in their developing relationship.

The wildlife in the film looks superb and the wild animals behave exactly like wild animals, red in tooth and claw. There's no sentimentality here, and the viewer is never spared the cruelties of nature. For this reason the film may be disturbing to young children despite its often enchanting visual content.

The Blu-ray 3D release contains a documentary film (itself in 3D) about the making of the film in which Lee explains how he conceived the film from the beginning as a 3D experience for the audience, and that this is the medium in which it needs to be seen. There's a lot of detail here for film buffs.

Some have chosen to nit-pick at details of the film and a few have disliked it; it may be that for those viewers this is just not the kind of story that floats their boat, so to speak. `Life of Pi' strives to explore deeper territory than the average Hollywood fare, in a highly original way. Lee succeeds in discussing the philosophy of religion; is there a creator and where can we experience evidence of it in nature? This is quite a difficult trick to pull off in a 127-minute film whilst entertaining the audience at the same time, but Lee's rare talent does just about manage it - and with a sting in the tail, too: at the end of the day, which story do you prefer?

... in the cameo role of the disgusting ship's cook. He should have been nominated at least for "Best Supporting Actor." Of course, the tiger deserved that even more, and all three avatars of Pi were incredible. The oldest Pi, the university teacher of religion in Canada, had a face nobody could distrust or dislike.

Needless to say, the cinematography was beyond incredible. I can only imagine how stunning it must be in 3-D; I watched it on a flat screen Panasonic 42-inch plasma and my jaw dropped dozen of times.

And that's it. Enough, shall I say, to join the thousand-plus reviewers who have awarded five stars? Only for the technical accomplishments, however. I found the "preaching" silly and annoying, just as i feared I would from having read the children's book upon which the film is based. To author Yann Martel and to director Ang Lee, I only this to say: Listen to Pi's Father! "Use your Reason!"

The more one reads about how the movie was made, the more there is to admire. This film is a treasure that will always hold secrets to be discovered.

The film is rated PG; if younger children have read books containing different types of fantasy and understand that films can also be "made up"--although they look very real--they should be comfortable seeing the film. The peril of the ship/storm and the subsequent events are the most intense, but it helps to remind children those are "imaginary."

"Life of Pi" transcends the concept of a story with a theme. It clearly demonstrates the existence of God. It's also wonderful storytelling. I believe this accounts for why it is so popular.

For a movie to appeal to my senses it must be about something that is not only interesting but that I would never expect to see happen in my everyday life. "Life of Pi" meets both of those criteria. To see wild animals on a lifeboat, and then to see a young man co-exist with a ferocious tiger on that lifeboat, and then to see both survive for many months while adrift in the middle of the ocean, simply defied my imagination.

The plot, although fantastic, is very well developed and proceeds logically, which adds to the credibility of the story. Reality is represented by mathematics and a traditional religious belief, which eventually gives way to a belief in a universal concept of the divine. In other words, it may not be enough to believe in only one religion anymore. By his becoming a follower of three religions, Pi's life is transformed. He demonstrates his universality throughout the story.

The basic plot of the story is one that many people might have thought of or written about. However, Yann Martel told this story in such a way as to make it more believable than if the plot were simply concocted from his imagination. All entities are equal when pitted against the forces of nature. It required a profound belief in God by Pi to enable him and his tiger companion to overcome enormous odds against their survival. The author brought this out in the story very well.
I thought it deserved its academiy award.  Kudos to the director.  Also to the young lead actor.  He was great.

It makes you feel like your right on the boat with the main character of the movie (Pi).  This movie never got boring, it just went from excitement  to excitement from start to finish.  As a avid animal lover, and lover of challenges and adventures of life myself, this was the perfect movie for me.  I highly recommend it !  It is well worth the rental price, and you will be thinking about the deeper message of faith and never giving up, after it is long over.  I give it 5 out of 5!!

Wow, what a pleasant surprise....even though i read the book i was still blown away by this totally unique & enthralling film.
This movie is moved by underlying currents of deep meaning that effectively pulled me in slowly but surely .... into a thought provoking heartfelt experience that left me glowing with new appreciation for life & all i share the journey with.
One reason i was able to be pulled so deeply into this was the acting....top notch, & the visuals are stunning... also....the actors are all fresh faces to me....so it bumped up the believability factor as there were no memories of past performances attached to the faces to pop up & interrupt the experience.
Seriously, the actor who plays the young Pi deserves an Academy award for this one.... or at least a standing ovation....HE made it believable....not the special effects.
Congratulations is in order for all involved in this masterpiece of a movie.
I put off seeing this because i figured since i had read the book...i would be encumbered by the "been there done that" syndrome....but strangely enough that was not the case at all even though it seemed to follow the books story line pretty closely.
I won't go into details, im sure there are plenty of reviews that are giving plot specifics...so i will wrap up the review by saying that this is one of the few movies that I KNOW i will be watching again soon...as there is just too much to take in, in just one viewing.

I'd heard good things about Pi and wanted to like it. However I found its philosophy to be puerile at best. I am not religious, however my understanding is that each religion believes in One True God... therefore the cherry-picking approach espoused by adult Pi would really offend believers of all faiths.

The awkward flashback structure (wherein adult Pi explains his childhood obsession with religion to his house guest) fails to drive the story forward. It just meanders until the ship sinking.

Finally the plot gets Pi in the boat with the animals, which leads to some gorgeous but empty CGI sequences at sea. There is nothing here in the "man vs. nature" portion that Melville, Hemingway, Heyerdahl or even the Noah legend already said better. Frankly, I turned Pi off after the god storm sequence and read a book. This crunchy New Age magical mystery tour was putting me to sleep.

Just watched Life of Pi, well made movie I must say... I was looking forward to "hearing a story which made me believe in God" sorry but doesnt it do the the exact opposite? Great advice from the father "I rather have you believe in something we disagree on than have you accepting everything blindly, and it all starts with thinking rationally"... Which version do I prefer? The one with the animals in it of course, now which do I believe or which is the "truth"? It is a question of whether you are a person to face a hard truth or do you route evidence for convenience and choose to believe a nice lie... It gives proof of how the idea of God is an invention of the human mind... Does it matter if the outcome of both stories was the same? Well, does the truth matter to you? I know it does to me... Do you search for answers or do you just have faith, period. If Pi was the tiger, then he ate part of the zabra (sailor) and he ate the hiena (cook)... He canivalized himself and invented a story to both forgive and cope with himself for the rest of his life... So he says "he brought out the evil in me, I have to live with that, I was alone in a boat and I survived" and "hunger can change everything you ever thought you knew about yourself"... Storytelling is fantastic though, well done!

Life of Pi asks big questions but leaves audiences with few answers. This latest Ang Lee movie is an adaptation of the eponymous novel by Yann Martel, which already had a large readership before Lee announced the upcoming film release. Life of Pi tells the story of Piscine Molitor Patel who grows up in India, where his father owns a zoo. He changes his name to "Pi" to avoid jokes about his name's homophonic similarities to the slang word for urination. The story could be divided into three acts: 1) his years growing up in India, 2) the shipwreck and his life as a castaway, 3) his reflections on his experiences.

The film begins with Pi speaking with a freelance writer. Pi's uncle told this writer that Pi had quite a story to tell and so the writer came to investigate. The film is Pi's narrative.

Though growing up a Hindu, Pi explores Christianity and Islam and finds admirable things in all there. In one scene he is engaged in praying to Allah on a prayer mat; the next shows him crossing himself before he eats. This sequence of shots, with the adult Pi narrating his exploration of religion, confronts the audience immediately with an "all paths lead to God" form of spirituality that is reflective of the contemporary milieu and the philosophy of John Hick. At this point, Lee has given the film profound religious dimensions.

Pi's father decides to move the family and bring the zoo animals along to sell in North America. On their way, a storm hits the cargo ship and Pi ends up being the sole survivor after being lowered in a lifeboat. The lifeboat also holds a hyena, an orangutan, a wounded Zebra, and a Bengal tiger named "Richard Parker." The hyena ends up eating the zebra alive, followed by killing the orangutan, only to be eaten by Richard Parker. Pi ends up fishing to feed the tiger so that he won't decide to eat Pi. They end up coming to an island, which they then leave after discovering that its ecosystem was carnivorous. The lifeboat ends up being washed ashore on the Mexican coast.

After they reach land, Richard Parker journeys into the jungle and leaves no trace behind. Representatives of the cargo ship owners visit Pi in the hospital to learn why the ship sank, but instead get Pi's extraordinary story of survival. They refuse to believe it, so Pi tells a metaphorical story whereby the Zebra is a wounded sailor, the orangutan is his mother, the hyena is the ship's callous cook, and Richard Parker is Pi himself.

Pi asks the writer which version of the saga he prefers. The animal version, he replies. Pi gives him the report filed by the ship company representatives, which reads that Pi held the record for shipwreck survivor longest at sea, and simply notes that he was accompanied by a Bengal tiger. We are left to interpret that comment ourselves. Does this last note demonstrate that there was evidence of a Bengal tiger on the ship and hence lends credence to Pi's story? Or does it merely indicate that the company representatives preferred the fantastical version?

Somehow the audience is expected to come full circle--the beginning of the film asks questions about God's existence and the human spiritual experience and the movie ends with Pi uttering cryptic lines that are supposed to have answered these questions. I left the theater rather unsatisfied, not because there were no answers, but because Lee failed to even provide the connection between the three parts of the film. We moved from big questions in the first part to an end that jumped to a vague interpretation of the castaway experience.

The clear import of the closing scene is that we can choose to view reality as mundane and material, or we can see it in all its manifold beauty that whispers the existence of God as corroborated by mindboggling providence. There is something inherent in us that wants to believe the latter and, lucky for us, the latter is true. If anything, Life of Pi is an argument for the existence of God based on the experience of beauty--whether it is physical beauty (the trailer shows jaw-dropping scenes of splendor that do not disappoint) or the beauty of storytelling.

Life of Pi oddly lacks a theodicy. It doesn't address the pain of why Pi's parents had to die and why there's a Darwinian food chain in the lifeboat. The story might be trying to go one-step more and relegate these painful episodes to being part of the conflict--a necessary component to any good story. And that's what we're wrapped up in: the story of the universal soul. This is intellectually rooted in Hindu-Buddhistic views of cyclical history that can celebrate such a story of suffering without demanding justice from a higher power.

To sum it up, the appetizer in the beginning and the dessert at the end tasted good, but the main course seemed completely unrelated to either. The whole time spent eating the main course was similar to an idyllic and eye-popping version of Tom Hanks's Castaway that singularly focused on survival. I have not read the book, so I'm not sure if Martel does a better job with this, but Lee's adaptation left something to be desired.

[This review was published previously on Schaeffer's Ghost ([...])]

People may choose to believe it but in all seriousness nobody really believes the story with the tiger because it's simply made up. After all the high judgments of this film at the Academy Awards, I was expecting something great, instead it was something boring.  I found myself wishing the tiger would eat the young man.  The only relief I felt when the boat landed on the Mexican coast was that the movie was finally over.

I'll probably get bashed for leaving this review by those who have read the book and who have a better understanding of the hidden meaning(s) in this movie. But I don't think a person's understanding of a film should be contingent on reading and completely grasping the novel prior.

The special effects were dazzling in and of themselves but they were distracting to the overall story line. Jellyfish don't fluoresce to the point of creating a "glow stick" effect making everything visible in the middle of the night in the middle of the ocean. Meerkats don't live on some "bionic island" in the Pacific nor do they sleep in trees. They burrow in the ground and live in Africa. So many times the water was way too calm and it was obvious they were filming (several) segments in a pool and it was obviously synthetic.

From other people's reviews it seems that the second story that involved real people was what really happened. But what felt so deflated was how so much attention and detail were devoted to the fantasy of story #1 that when the second story was told in a mere forty seconds - I felt so ripped off. Maybe a brief visual or some flashbacks capturing the violent/turbulent time with the human survivors might have made it more salvageable. It came off as poorly executed and something quickly tossed into the movie.

For me this movie didn't make me ponder or embrace a higher power. This is what we're supposed to think simply because he survived a ship wreck? God spared him? What about the people in the supposed second story (what really happened) who didn't survive like his mother and the cook and sailor? If the story were told from their point of view we'd have a very depressing movie pondering that there is no god at all. Instead we are fed a sugar-coated, extravagant lie and now we're supposed to feel all warm and fuzzy inside. So much detail paid to fantasy and the animation and not nearly enough to details and to conveying a consistent and infallible message. Oh and that last scene with the Tiger slowly walking into the jungle as if to say, "See ya, wouldn't wanna be ya." left me totally flat. I expected too much, I guess.

They must have made several copies of this DVD to sale because that is the only reason why it would not play in my DVD player. It does not play on regular DVD players. Trust me. I tried it on mine, my parents', and my grandfather's with no luck. It keeps saying bad disc. I could play it on the computer, tv/dvd combo and even my small radio/cd/tv/dvd portable boombox type, though. I returned it, and received a new one that did the same thing. I did not want to go through the hassle to return it, so I had to connect my boombox to my tv in lieu of my actual dvd player to get this to play on my tv. This is terrible. All my other dvds play even one that was new that I had not gotten around to opening.

It definitely could have been shorter because there's really not much you can work with with a kid stuck on a boat for a long time. I ended up falling asleep during the movie because it was so boring to me. It struck me as odd how many people got involved in the metaphysical debate over whether or not this extremely well crafted film actually stands as a "proof" of God.  I do not believe the film even attempts to "prove" the existence of God, at least not in any scientific or empirical sense of the word "proof".  Instead, the film presents an excellent humanist justification for faith, one that deftly avoids the scientific debate by focusing on preferences rather than proof (e.g. "Which story do you prefer?").
One of the best movies I've seen in a long while.  It holds you at the edge of your seat as well as makes you think.
It was a very enjoyable movie, one I could watch with my grandchildren.  We all enjoyed it. I would tell people to watch it.
Go log in and buy this now!  Don't think about it make a move.  This is an awesome visual experience.

I read the book when it came out, but don't remember it.  With the movie, as soon as I realized Pi's family died at sea, I lost interest - I didn't believe it at first and kept waiting for them to return.  Anyway, all the actors playing Pi were good, but for me, Pi as part of his entire wonderful family was the draw in the story, and as soon as I understood his family was lost, I became brokenhearted and emotionally left the film.  I was happy Pi survived, but Pi's mother and father were so interesting, had such different parenting strategies and outlooks on life, yet managed to give their son so much knowledge and wealth in love and care, that he survived nearly a year shipwrecked - their loss was too huge for me.

I had a hard time telling the difference between the computer animation and real animals.  The story line was also really good considering it was about a boy on a boat with a tiger (sounded kind of boring at first).  My kids also really enjoyed it.
