For its technical accomplishments alone, Ang Lee's LIFE OF PI is likely to rank at the top of the list of 2012's best for many viewers, and there's no doubt from an artistic standpoint, its visuals were unmatched by any other film last year.

An adaptation of Yann Martel's seemingly impenetrable rumination on the triumph of the human spirit, man's place in the universe, and the role of religion in an individual's spiritual journey, "Life of Pi" is, first and foremost, a film for the senses. Working from a script by David Magee, director Lee's film follows "Pi" Patel (Suraj Sharma), a young man who learns of different religions growing up in the Puducherry region of what was once French India. His inquisitive nature, both encouraged by his mother (Tabu) and discouraged by a father (Adil Hussain) who operates a zoo in their town, is scuttled as he grows older and his family is eventually forced to immigrate to Canada. En route, the Japanese freighter carrying them, as well as their zoo animals, is wrecked in a storm, with only Pi escaping - alongside a zebra, orangutan, hyena, and a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker, who journeys with Pi on an ocean teeming with both peril and wonder, with florescent jellyfish lighting up the world beneath them and humpback whales catapulting through the air.

"Life of Pi" is so staggeringly, jaw-droppingly beautiful that Lee and cinematographer Claudia Miranda's effective use of the 3-D format is evident from the movie's first frames. Long before Pi and Richard Parker set out on a lifeboat of individual discovery, "Life of Pi" has already captivated the viewer with its fascinating portrait of young Pi's life in French India, with gorgeous landscapes, colors and animals filling each and every frame. Most of the movies we see using 3-D employ it merely as a gimmick to goose grosses, but much like Martin Scorsese's "Hugo," Lee here frames so many sequences with depth-of-field dimension that its inclusion ranks as an absolute necessity to appreciating the spellbinding images that Lee and Miranda - both of whom were deservedly honored with Oscars, alongside composer Mychael Danna and the visual effects team at Rhythm & Hues - generated here.

The film's story is another matter; one can easily see why readers of Martel's book were drawn to the material, for its mostly ambiguous, take-out-what-you-put-in take on world religion and faith, in general, functions mostly as a byproduct of the individual reader. On-screen, Lee is able to invest the material with a similar cloudiness, though that ambiguity is harder to achieve in a medium like film. There's no outright sermonizing in the picture, but its ending is more forcefully tilted in one direction than the more hazy conclusion Martel originally wrote. Still, however obvious (or not) the film's metaphorical messages and spiritual philosophizing happen to be, there's no question "Life of Pi" is a film that's impossible to forget and easy to appreciate on a sheer artistic level. Whether or not you find it to be as enriching an emotional journey will be - much like its source material - up to the individual viewer.

Fox's 3-D Blu-Ray presentation of "Life of Pi" is unquestionably a must-view for any 3-D home theaterphile. The images, composition and clarity of the 3-D are spectacular throughout, and as I wrote before, few films have demanded viewing in the 3-D format more than "Life of Pi." The 3-D Blu-Ray also includes nearly 15 minutes of exclusive deleted scenes, plus the trailer in 3D and visual effects progressions (these exclusive extras can also be played in a standard BD player). Other supplements on the standard Blu (which features a dazzling 1080p AVC encoded transfer in its own right) boast several featurettes, an art gallery and storyboards, while a DVD and digital copy round out the disc. The DTS MA 7.1 audio is impressively mounted as well, highlighting another fine score written by Danna for his long-time cinematic collaborator.

One final note on "Life of Pi": it's inconceivable to me that this picture generated a PG rating from the MPAA. With its marketing campaign dominated by images of Pi and the tiger together in the lifeboat, I have no doubt there were parents who took children to this film, only to be horrified by the animal violence that occurs in it - even if it's off-camera and isn't gratuitous, this isn't a film for young kids, and should've absolutely received a PG-13 for that and the generally intense tone of the picture. Of course, this isn't the first sign our ratings system is dysfunctional - merely the latest evidence of it.

Ang Lee's presentation of the Life of Pi was a delight to me. I loved this book when I first read it, and I had trouble getting it out of my head for months.  My experience with movies made from books that I have loved has been mixed - some of the movies have been enjoyable and some have been disappointing, all for many and varied reasons, so I settled down in front of the flat screen TV to watch Life of Pi with my best open mind.

Although it has been a few years since I read the book, the movie brought it back to me in waves of memories.  The film was visually stunning to me (You must stream this movie in HD to be stunned), and I didn't feel cheated by not having it in 3D, since the 5.1 surround sound was enough realism for me.  The tiger was magnificently created and was as real to me as any real tiger could be.  The love that Pi and Richard Parker shared developed as tenderly as any love story could, and showed the reality of human misperception of "taming" a wild animal. Pi was convincinly played as an adorable, if somewhat irascible, young man and as an engaging, deeply thoughtful adult.

As with the book, the movie left me totally satisfied with the experience of the story, and with renewed questions about which version of Pi's story was really real. As with the book, in the end it didn't matter to me, because the story was so engaging, so entertaining and so lovely.

This is an extremely unique movie with incredible characters, humor, sadness, and thought provoking moments all rolled into one.  The Life of Pi is a fantastic escape from the violent, floor shaking movies we have grown used to. A tale that I am certain will become a classic.

This film is truly exceptional.  It is also very difficult.  I do not want to ruin the experience for you so I offer a few pieces of advice while watching and nothing more...

1.  Keep an open mind.  There are many messages that are not fully revealed until the end.  This is made more difficult because these seemingly separate messages do tie in to a much broader message that is revealed almost simultaneously.

2.  The VFX are spectacular but the film is not meant to be a spectacle.  There is meaning to be found in almost every component of the story.

3.  When finished, research the story.  Specifically the names of characters and how they are related to actual historical events.

4.  Enjoy and suspend disbelief...  This is a carefully nuanced piece of art intended to affect change in the viewer.

It is my belief this story is intended to change the world.  Not that it actually will but the message is incredibly broad and idealistic.  Some people may find the message reassuring while others may find it disturbing.  What worries me is that in many ways this is art for artists.  It requires analysis and information beyond what is presented but that is part of it's beauty.

Amazing performances by the main character played by Suraj Sharma. The imagery is key to this film with staggeringly beautiful sights you can't even imagine presented magnificently. Prepare to be moved and amazed.

LIFE OF PI is visually stunning.  I observed tigers at close quarters for years as a volunteer at a preserve for big cats.  I was completely fooled by the CGI in the creation of "Richard Parker," although I began to catch on when the tiger did things it was difficult for me imagine a tiger doing, like climbing into a boat or catching and eating a live rat flung at it.  In terms of the story, these moves seemed possible, given the extreme circumstances the tiger was in.  I just wasn't sure of a real tiger, a Hollywood working animal, being successfully trained to do these things.

The action at heart is an old-fashioned adventure tale of survival at sea with an unusual twist, told more with humor than desperation.  It strives to present the story as a spiritual one, but like the journalist (an off-putting performance by Rafe Spall.  Why would a stranger open up to this blank, boring boob?) I was underwhelmed by that aspect.  The "inspirational" thrust felt scrambled and overreaching, and once Pi is at sea, secondary.  I had only a tenuous idea by the end what all this was supposed to have to do with God.  Part of the problem may have been the sound in the all-important reveal Pi makes to the insurance investigators at the end.  Suraj Sharma's accent was too thick and his speech too fast for me to catch a lot of what he said.  Was it me, or was the sound poorly handled in this scene?  I've seen the film three times--still can't get it all.

But I got the tiger.  Who hasn't felt at times trapped, abandoned, marooned, to face a proverbial tiger of some sort in our own lives completely on our own?  When Pi attributes his survival to Richard Parker for keeping him alert and active, the emotional truth resonated.  Overcoming a challenge to survival has been the making of many a man or woman.

The greatness of this film lies not in its metaphors but in its awesome visual sweep.  I've never seen water look so crystal clear on screen.  Its appearance alone carries mystical implications.  The movie needs to be seen on the big screen to get its full meaning, for on the big screen the water not only thrills but illuminates.  Note that in the editorial review above, Kathleen Fennessey compares the brutal storm in this movie to TITANIC.  Puzzling, as there is no "horrific" storm in TITANIC.  Perhaps she meant to compare it to THE PERFECT STORM--whatever--but she's got her storms, and her movies, scrambled.  The water effects in LIFE OF PI range from being as shimmering and evocative as a Monet painting, to being a terrifying cataclysm.  TITANIC has nothing to compare with it.  In LIFE OF PI, the water is alive, one of the primary characters, and makes the movie come alive.

We watched this on our family movie night with our daughters ages 10 and 13, without having read any reviews or having any idea of what the movie is about.  Our 10 year old thought it was scary, but huddled close to her dad and made it through the whole thing.  The movie and plot is quite engaging; it's hard to know what is "real" and what is imagined -- until the end.  It was too metaphorical for our kids to understand -- and that is probably a good thing, given what the main character had to do to survive.  It was pretty thought-provoking -- after-the-fact -- for the adults who watched.  Our kids watched the whole thing, but they really didn't enjoy it very much.

Life of Pi is an emotional story, but well balanced. Tension builds but is released with some genuinely humorous lines, and none of it seems overplayed. If you've seen the trailer, you know that a boy ends up shipwrecked with a tiger. So - you'll spend the first bit of the movie wondering how this happens, and the second half of the movie wondering how he manages to make it out alive - that was enough to keep me keen to watch. And yes, he spends a long time in that boat, but that's how the story goes. After awhile I started to get antsy - when is he finally going to get out of that blasted boat?! That's just a snippet of the emotion that Pi must have endured. Any movie that makes me feel what the character feels is a winner in my book, and it happened throughout the movie.

I am not a spiritual person and I definitely had to chew on the closing lines for a bit until I was satisfied with its meaning. If you don't want to reflect on life a bit, perhaps you should skip this film.

My only complaint - fabulous acting and filming, but some of the CGI was distracting. Maybe it looked better in 3D at the theater?

This is a great book, and a great story.  The protagonist is well cast at both stages of his life, and the story -- not a fast-paced one -- proceeds at an appropriate clip, without boring the viewer.  But perhaps most important is the stunning cinematography that Ang Lee is so known for.  The story of Pi will stay with you, and the ending is wonderful, but what might be most memorable is the brilliance and unbelievable beauty of every shot.  In that regard, this is basically Mother Nature's response to Avatar -- and she wins.
The special effects were awesome; the story not so much.  I wish I had seen it in 3D which would be incredible.

Ang Lee's "Life of Pi" is a masterpiece of state-of-the-art film making, a beautiful creation that tells a moving story in heart-touching way.

Starting from the very opening credits, it is a gorgeous film to watch.  Filmed in vibrant color and mostly natural settings, with animals featured in many scenes, it is more visually stunning than any nature documentary I've ever seen.  The scenes at sea, both at night under the stars and during the day, under a wide variety of different ocean conditions, show the true beauty and terrifying power of the open ocean.  Certainly some of the scenes, especially the phosphoresence scenes, are computer enhanced, but the net effect is spectacular.

The animals, especially the Bengal tiger, are the costars of the movie, and their actions are incredibly lifelike and true to their animal nature.  This is no Disney film - in only one short scene does the tiger exhibit any humanlike traits.  I have no idea how Ang Lee actually created and captured these animal scenes on film - the special effects are so good, with no hints of fakery, that you will believe that all the scenes really were filmed at sea with the lead actor on a small boat alongside a hungry, vicious tiger.  This is present-day special effects at its absolute best, and in service to a movie that is not a science fiction shoot-em-up.  Impressive.

The movie's story is about stories: how they are created and retold, and the impact they have on people.  "Life of Pi" has some interesting things to say about religion, because the documents at the heart of all major religions are effectively books of stories, very little of which can actually be proven or verified to have happened.  Pi's story about what happened at sea on his boat where he was the only human survivor is no different, and when you can't scientifically verify something, the question becomes what do you believe?  "Life of Pi" leaves it to the viewer to decide.

"Life of Pi" is quite an achievement for director Ang Lee.  I think I know why Hollywood voted the "Hollywood saves the day" film Argo as the Oscar's Best Picture of 2012, but "Life of Pi" is a far better and much more memorable movie.

I will admit that when i first saw the trailer for this, i misjudged this movie. I thought to myself "what a ridiculous looking  movie." But recently I found out I was completely dead wrong about this Film. I do not know where to begin. Suraj Sharma plays the title character Pi and he does it realistically. Pi is everything I would hope to be in his situation: brave, courageous, and daring. This movie also proves (and does a really good job at it) that help can come from the most unlikely ally. That being said, the storyline is top notch in this film and it is deeply moving. The supporting cast is good, but the surprise in this film (and i think many will agree) are the effects and visuals. Ang Lee Deserves not only a tip of the hat, but in my opinion he deserves a standing ovation for making such an enjoyable film. Quoting one of the lines from the film "I was told you have a story that would make me believe in God,"  And in my honest opinion, this film has done that and so much more. 5 stars

The evaluation and following review is about the 3D Blu Ray release, not the film itself, which is excellent.  Though the 3D of the disc is very nice, it bothers me to no end that the film was cropped from 2.35:1 to 16x9 for this disc release.  This is a nasty habit from the days of 4x3 VHS and it seems to become common with 3D releases  again.  Cameron did the same to Avatar and Titanic, taking away the grandeur from both films along the way.  Stranger yet in Life of Pi Fox opted to curtain the Imax shot on the Blu Ray to make sure audiences would see the full shot, yet with the exception of a single scene the sides of the rest of the film are chopped off.  So this is for the people responsible:  If you have the balls to charge $30 for a disc, you better release the movie with it's complete picture on the 3D version, especially since you feel the need to release multiple versions packaged into one release anyway!  From this point on any 3D Blu Ray I encounter with it's aspect ratio mutilated will go straight back to the vendor.  I encourage everyone else to do the same, in an attempt to stop this!

The Life of Pi explores the depths of the human soul and spirit and exemplifies the metamorphisis that occurs when people of faith are pushed to their weekest points. Sound heavy right? This was a really good effort at showing the dichotomy between man and beast.  It makes you think about life and what you would do in a similar situation.  Of course, sharing a boat with a Bengal Tiger is pure theatre (you wouldn't last a millisecond).  The movie was technically a winner.  I did not find any fault with the action scenes.  You really thought Richard Parker was only a few feet away.  Also, I liked that Ang Li did not go after any excessive bloody scenes that you would see in other productions.  I recommend this film to anyone old enough to understand.  Finally, I'm considering reading the book.  I would say this is very high praise.

The story starts actually from the family decision of selling the animals and ends when Pi lands.

The movie itself is very good but I had problems with the audio throughout the movie. The picutre quality was very good. However, at times the video would continue without an audio track. At other times the audio would slow down to being only noise while the video continued at the regular speed. Through the middle of the movie the audio ran in sync with the video for several minutes but then the audio would slow down. On numerous times, I would stop the movie, then resume and the audio would be in sync for about 1 to 2 minutes, then slow down. Twice the movie stopped to continue loading. With all the stops and starts, I barely finished the movie before time expired. I still didn't get to watch and listen to all the movie and understand all that happened. I have watched other movies from Amazon without ever having this problem. But if the future movies have this trouble I'll stop watching on Amazon and use another service or I'll go to a theater to see it.

Life of Pi is an incredible story of an incredible experience.  I've heard debate about the truthfulness of the story and that doesn't matter at all.  There are countless lessons to be learned in this story and Ang Lee has presented them in such a beautiful way, that the authenticity doesn't matter at all.  This is just a gorgeous movie and can be enjoyed on countless levels.

I watched LOP two weeks ago; so I've had a chance to think about how I felt about the movie.

I normally choose to watch only those movies that are given high marks, so as to not waste time. It didn't matter to me that this movie was nominated for an academy award for best picture. I found myself having low expectations. I find that whenever I have low expectations for a movie, the movie surprises me and I enjoy it. Somehow, this felt different.

I think it's because LOP is easily was one of the best books I've ever read.

Maybe it's because the movie didn't have any mystery? Granted, I knew what to expect from the plot, but I'm the type of guy who eats the same food over and over, and re-reads books and re-watches movies, so mystery isn't necessarily why I do anything.

I preferred the version of the story in the book.  There are some noticeable differences. Studying theology, the reporter is a female, Pi's marriage, etc.

It felt like... the movie's version of the story was told in a rushed way. IMO, best lines of the movie were taken directly from the book. So, The movie didn't suspend disbelief the way the book did. Examples: this should come as no surprise, but the book goes into far more detail about the 'taming' of RP; the floating island was move alive and even more of a curiosity in the book than the treatment it had in the movie; etc. Those details were lost and neglected in the translation.

BL: I'll read the book again for pleasure, but you couldn't pay me to watch the movie again, it's not worth the time.

The CG Tiger was beautiful but the whale was so obviously fake among other things.  And the movie was unrealistic it is more like a story of legend than reality.  Also, I searched online an the longest time I found of someone being lost at sea was 22-year-old Poon Lim's 133 days alone.  When I watch these types of films I often think about what it would be like to really be stuck in that situation but the movies was so unrealistic that it was almost a dream world than reality and nothing like what it would really be like.  Also, I wonder what people in India think of this film.
The beautiful visual effects and great story were compromised somewhat by the questions raised at the end. Definitely worth watching.

I gave it two stars instead of one because the CGA was incredible.  But the movie itself was awful.  Long, slow and boring.  One hour of "I'm really afraid of the tiger."  That's not an exaggeration.  One.  Hour.  And nothing happens.  In fact, little happens in the movie from beginning to end.  Avoid at all costs.

The Life of Pi is a fable-like story that has been brought to the screen by an astounding director. The visuals of this film were worth the purchase price. The story requires the ability to suspend belief and let the viewer's mind open itself to the experience in order to enjoy the film and receive the full impact. If you are a person who views a film with the sole purpose of picking it apart, you'll be disappointed because you missed the story.

I recommend this film for all ages.
we liked it, enjoyed the cinematography, it moved a little slowly at first, but overall, an enjoyable way to spend an evening.
Great film! Keeps you interested from beginning to end! When you think you have it all figured out you are shocked with a meaningful twist.

This is a nice flick.  To me, the symbolism was overdone.  The ending left me a bit cold.  Visually, very beautiful, but all animation.  So why it was nominated and won at the Oscars is a little baffling.  The subject of the animation was amazing and portrayed very sweetly.  The story was OK.  The writing was OK.  I guess perhaps I had higher expectations as an Oscar nominee than I felt it delivered.  I'm not sure, with all the superb animation and computer graphics that exist in the world these days, why this movie was so chatted-up.  I found it to be a faux-myth without much substance at all.  With all that said, it's worth the rental fee, perhaps a good purchase.  If you want to know 'everything' that can be done on a computer, then it's worth it as well.  A little disappointed.
Kept my attention. Laugh, cry, jump, didn't like some scenes of survival on the animal parts, but overall a good experience.

(I have 3 rescues, can't afford more, and it breaks my heart I can't save them all). I donate as much as I can.  Apparently, it won some awards, many awards, I didn't watch. Ang Lee does it again with this tale of a young man and his survival of a shipwreck only to be trapped on a lifeboat with a live tiger. I must admit that I am not at all familiar with the book, so I bring no book-laden expectations to the film. I saw this film strictly on the basis of a few trailers I saw that intrigued me. I love the visual splendor of the tiger, and the menace of the tiger at close quarters was absolutely terrifying. The great cosmic meaning of the film may have escaped me, but I was transfixed at the sight of this beautiful and deadly beast and the young man playing a cat and mouse game with him in the lifeboat. I was well entertained, and am not worried if I should have had a profound insight and did not. The film is like a moving breathing work of art, and it captured my attention for every minute of it's length, which is something that I can't say about many films these days. If you enjoyed PI, you might also consider Beasts of the Southern Wild. If you have a fascination with wild animals, especially tigers, grab this DVD asap! If you want the deeper meaning, I'm sure someone will explain it to you until your eyes glass over.
i love the animation in this movie over and over to get all the points i missed plus i love big cats

 Overall, a very good movie with a compelling story and excellent visual effects.

My immediate reaction after watching this film in 3D..."Stunning, absolutely stunning!" It is a great story, compelling and powerful: part survival story, part fantasy, part animal psychology...and all in glorious 3D visual artistry. It is also the story of faith; although the protagonist, Pi Patel's approach to God is an ambiguous one, in that he espouses the Hindu, Christian and Islamic faiths. At one point his father says, "following multiple faiths is no faith at all!"; and I would agree, but somehow Pi's simplicity of faith is believable. While the lion's (or Tiger's) share for the excellence of this film - my opinion - should go to Ang Lee, the performance by 17 year old Suraj Sharma, in his film debut, as Pi Patel, should not be overlooked. It is in many ways a masterful performance, not often attained by experienced actors twice or three times his age. The CGI/special effects, which like the cast, is international in scope, is also a wonder to behold...even if you do not care for the story, the visuals make the movie worth watching. And the story...look for a twist at the end that will likely surprise you.

A classic!! Loved it! My kids can't stop talking about it. Ang Lee  is a wonderful director. Exquisite imagery. Ang Lee is pretty damn amazing. Here is a Chinese filmaker with an ouvre that includes such varied work as Brokeback Mountain, Hulk, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Eat Drink, Man Woman, Lust, Caution, and now Life of Pi (all except for Hulk pretty brilliant). That one man can capture both the unique Chinese flavor of Crouching Tiger and the Western American rhythm of Brokeback. Amazing.

Now we have this film, which resists all categorization. At one level, it's an eminently watchable survival adventure and pure visual treat. I haven't read the book yet (I will now), but I have to asume it has a fable-like quality, and so does the film. The color alone is surreal and intense. The cinematography is gorgeous. Some of the shots... woah. There is some odd unreal nighttime lighting here too -- although it works. There is very heavy use of shallow depth of field to good effect.

It's worth noting that I saw the film in 3D, which has clearly graduated from three years ago when it was only for the likes of Alice in Wonderland (hiss) and How to Train Your Dragon. Now we have it in high budget literary adventure religious allegory. Interestingly, I'm pretty convinced that 3D has the effect of decreasing realism. It makes everything look like CGI, heightened, super-real, like an HDR photograph.

The acting is also superb. The casting of Pi at various ages is dead on. All three are highly emotive. And the tiger -- who is presumably 90% CGI -- he's the stuff of legend. There is one damn cool animal. The soggy cat hanging off the side of the boat is just so sad, lest us forget that the Bengal Tiger is the world's most dangerous land animal. Tiger's are fast, deadly, climb, swim, and can bat your head off with one paw. Imagine sharing a lifeboat with one! There's a 19th century tiger known to have killed over 430 men.

The film is to beautiful, that the ocean itself, and its bevy of sea life, becomes a character. As desperate as Pi (and Richard Parker the Tiger) are, they can't help but marvel at the little seen wonders that present, and us with them.

Thematically, I'm not yet sure how to digest Life of Pi. It's a pretty deeply emotional movie, and at some level plays to the film medium's visual strengths. The picture hints at deeper philosophical notes, but doesn't really illuminate. I sense extreme abbreviation. After all, 450 pages of novel would result in perhaps six hours of film.

Andy Gavin, author of The Darkening Dream and Untimed
I was so taken back by this movie I went out and bought the blue ray after watching it, very well done. The story was great and emotional ! the visuals were breathtaking, I loved it.

A VERY INSPIRATIONAL MASTERPIECE OF ART.  THE PRESENTATION MADE REFLECT ON MYSELF AND THE CURRENT PROBLEMS OF THE WORLD.  THE PRESENTATION OF THE LIFE OF PI SHOULD BE AN ESSENTIAL PART OF EVERY FAMILY'S AUDIO VISUAL LIBRARY, TO BE VIEWED AND DISCUSSED BY THE ENTIRE FAMILY AT THE SAME TIME.

I saw the movie not knowing much about the story.  The trailers didn't quite pique my interest.  I thought it was a beautiful movie with a vainglorious story about a protagonist and its pet tiger.

Boy, was I wrong.  This turned out to be such a wonderful film with such an inspiring story, it moved me to tears.

But the movie (and the story) isn't perfect.  One thing I didn't quite appreciate was Pi's pronouncement for "God"--although I can see how odd it would've been for him to call out "33 million Hindu gods" or "Allah."  As a atheist, I didn't quite care for the religious value of the story.

Nonetheless, his story of finding hope in life after a total loss is worth the time to watch over and over.

This film is appealing on many levels.  Many human characters are attractive in different ways, though the writer is only a foil, not even as developed as the interviewer in "Interview with the Vampire."  The central character, Pi, is so engrossing and the development of his life is so captivating that only his immediate family are relevant in the film.  Some animals are significant, but the Bengal Tiger embodies powerful forces of Nature with which we are obliged to become aware and learn to live with.  The trials that Pi has to go through speak to the common challenges of the human condition, but are exaggerated in ways that, thankfully, most of us don't have to experience.  They are illustrative of the human search for meaning and purpose, and for ethical and moral ways of being in the world.  The story has a smoothly coherent ending that leaves us with a warm glow, contentedly chewing a cud of psychological, philosophical, and spiritual questions and feeling ourselves worthy because of it.

Awesome Epic Journey into Spirituality and Academy Award Recommended. I was astounded How Epicly Amazing it truly was a heart moving expeirnece and forwardwith the human spirit to survive with spritual reasoning.

As the title of this review states, I had no idea what "Life of Pi" was about.  I went in totally blind, thinking it was a simple adventure story.  What I found was visually pleasing and spiritually empty.  Mind you, I had no idea there was supposed to be any spiritual element to this film but when I was fully informed of the spiritual message (mostly at the very end of the film) I found that it strongly detracted from an otherwise great story.  In fact, had there been no spiritual message at all and simply a film about how some cope with traumatic events, OR had it been a chronicling of Pi's spiritual pursuits I might have enjoyed it much more.  It is neither but tries to be both.
I read some of the other reviews and many people comment that this movie is about a spiritual journey.  In reality there is no spiritual journey to speak of after the introduction of young Pi and his fascination with several prominent religions.  The rest of the story is nothing more than a fantasy concocted by Pi in order to cope with a very ugly and traumatic experience.  There is no spiritual journey contained in that entire section of the movie, just the stressed and desperate musings of a boy struggling to stay alive and sane on the open ocean.  Somehow, the very personal emotional significance of this experience is seen as valid ground to make a universal spiritual statement about God.  It doesn't require much thought to understand the folly of taking such a ridiculous liberty.  Therein the true intentions of the writer are revealed and the full weight of the emptiness of this film hits you like bad breath, momentarily offensive but of no real import.  Were it not for the movie's amazing visuals and the excellent acting of Suraj Sharma (a complete amateur no less!) I would have given it one star, as it is, it remains well directed and acted but poorly conceived.

An incredible visual experience (and a magical combination of characters) on screen to be sure, but the depth of allegory that this parable manages to express and finally reveal at the end into a literal concrete "meaning" is utterly poignant and only the most clueless (or darkened) soul of a person can hope to reject the value in the message being expressed here.  This isn't a preachy film at all, and its appeal is that is reaches out and touches everyone capable of being an audience to it. How important is it to understand the many ways in which a truth can be expressed? How important and vital to our understanding and growth to not dogmatize or demonize a contrary method to that truth if there be one?

I can't say any more for fear of spoiling it to the unaware concerning the details of the story (so watch it!!) - But suffice it to say that this film was one of those "OH S*** that's amazing" moments for me, at the level of experience all too rare in its potency in this industry, and one that I'm thankful to have experienced.

The 411 by Maria:

In it's most basic form the movie is about Pi Patel, the only human survivor after his parents commission a ship to move their zoo from India to Canada. Along with Pi is an orangutan, a hyena, a zebra that broke it's leg when it feel into the life boat and an adult Bengal Tiger (who is named Richard Parker).

After the other animals are killed by tiger, Pi and the Tiger learn to coexist on and off the life boat until Pi is rescued in Mexico 227 days after the ship went down.

OK...now that I gave you that very brief summary, let's get into how and why I liked it so much. The movie is exquisitely done with amazing cinematography and CGI effects. I truly love how beautiful it was and wish I had seen it in 3D!

Pi played by Suraj Sharma as the shipwrecked younger Pi and later Irrfan Khan as older Pi, is amazingly resourceful as he struggles to keep himself and Richard Parker alive.

My husband says it reminded him of Tom Hanks Castaway, I can see why he would say that but visually, it is way above Castaway.

Very cool effects!

An amazing story of wonder, awe, gratitude and optimism.

I've never read the book, so the movie was my first exposure to the original story. From a viewer's point of view, despite its remarkable visual and narrative mastery, "Pi" felt like just another high-quality Hollywood production - one that makes you feel good but is easily forgettable - until the story took a suddenly turn toward the end and Pi confronted us with the brutal truth and challenged our faith in humanity with the ultimate question: "which story do you prefer?". Without the last 10 minutes "Pi" is a 3-star movie; with its last 10 minutes it easily claims 5. Thanks to his extraordinary cinematic talent, director Ang Lee was able to do justice to the story itself - that is no small feat.

"Pi" is not a religious movie - not in the sense that it preaches anything. It simply asks us a question and leaves the rest to us. For some of us it's uplifting; for the rest of us it does nothing - until a later time.
An interesting story but a little slow at the beginning. This has agood story line and was of good quality in HD.

Being a sincere fan of Ang Lee's oeuvre, I was already inclined to favor this movie beforehand - and more so after it didn't turn stupid or fall apart in the third act, like too many epic films by big name directors. However, I still enjoyed those other movies, mostly.

On one level this is a spectacularly filmed survival tale, but it is much more than that. It follows the book very closely. The attempt of the character as a boy to integrate all the religions of the world is put to another sort of test by the voyage--how to integrate the human and animal dimensions of himself, to see beyond his mother's and father's competing and contradictory visions of an irrational and deep world of spirit versus a rational world of learning skillful manipulation. The pacifist, vegetarian boy must move beyond those beliefs to find the ferocity of survival within himself, the intensity of the carnivorous Richard Parker--his traveling mate tiger, who brings him into a confrontation with the depths and expanse of a larger universe under the night sky and mirroring waves. What the rational and calculative world represented by the Japanese ship-owners can see in this tale is only one of human manipulation and competition, but what the man can see as  greater depths of this story and its reality is a cosmic coming together of dimensions that are archetypal and the expansion of spirit grounded in the earth and the animal. It is not an untroubled vision, where carnivorous islands of the soul float in the depth of the night to disturb us.

Without the stunning visual images in the "adrift at sea" section of the movie, the viewer might despair of Pi's fate. Yet this movie is really about his journey in spirit. After having to leave India with his family, the boy becomes the lone human survivor after the cargo ship they were taking passage to North America is scuttled in a typhoon off the Philippines. In India they had been the operators of a small zoo. Some of their animals made the trip and 3 in particular survived the initial shipwreck. Some of the spiritual dynamics introduced including Krishna are brought out as Pi learns to deal with his ferocious companion, a Bengal tiger named Richard Parker and as the days lengthen to months at sea with little hope of survival we see how he envisions the world of the sea in fantastic luminous images. He first lands on a strange island which is hospitable by day and hostile by night by virtue of pure waters turning acidic by night. Later he washes up in Mexico where his longtime companion tiger just calmly walks into the forest without a look back. This upsets him and then a strange twist occurs when he is asked by Japanese authorities to account for his being the only survivor of the wrecking of their cargo ship. His story is too fantastic for them so he tells them another one which is more sinister yet more plausible. The allegory is caught by his listener as he retells the story many years later. The spiritual lesson is what do you wish to believe, the boy floating across the Pacific with a tiger or a boy who escaped evil doers.

Epic. This movie had me thinking about it the next day and that is something special. A movie that captivates and causes viewers to fall into the world it portrays and form thoughts is simply that: epic.

This is an exciting film during the second half, but the first half took too long to develope the storyline.  I still loved the special effects and the last few lines in the movie.  Can't tell you,  watch it.

It is true this movie is a work of art.  The visuals are stunning and beautiful.  I understood the movie and enjoyed it.  I purchased the movie as a possible book and film study for my high school seniors.  Not sure they will make it through the movie without falling asleep as there are many slow sections.  That being said, many of the slow parts are complemented with thought-provoking scenary and action.  That is part of the beauty and mystery of the movie.  I do not understand the many reviews saying this was a horror movie.  Horror, in film, is a lot different than a horrific life experience.  It is not a "horror movie".  As for the animals...one of the themes of the film is survival and also living on the planet with other species which God has created (all unique in their own way).  Animals eat one another in the wild and we eat animals too.  My domestic cats sitting here on the table beside me just ate their tuna and Fancy Feast, which, I believe still has meat in it.  If you watched this with your children and they cried all the way through...I don't believe you.  None of the scenes with animals eating one another were even slightly gruesome.  There was not any blood or carnage.  Reviewers, please know what you are talking about before you review...and focus on the story.  If you do watch this with your children...there is a lot you will need to explain to them.

Multiple times throughout the movie the quality shot way down.  Amazons video quality indicator on screen would show low bandwidth so I would run a speed test at that time to determine if my provider was to blame.  I would get 40mbs down and 5mbs up while the video quality would remain very poor.  My TV was hard wired and not streaming over wireless.

I won't be using Amazons service for HD anymore, this was very disappointing and a complete waste of money. As I mentioned the directing and visuals were pure eye candy, yet so tastefully and expertly done that they serve to pull you into the story rather than distract you from it.  Toss in some deep revelations that will leave you in self reflection long after the credits role and you have a modern day masterpiece that is very hard to come by these ADD days and harder to just walk away from when the screen finally goes black.

This is one of the most difficult movies I've had to review in a long time.
Why?
Because almost everything I've read has been positive and yet every review has had a much different take on the overall meaning of the film.
I was expecting a spiritual rebirth for myself somewhat.
Unrealistic yes, but that is the kind of praise that's been heaped on this film.
I was expecting a movie that was life changing.
Well...it wasn't.
I didn't get either of those things and yet I don't feel cheated either.
And that is the real magic of this film...that everyone will take away something different.
Me?
I took away a real sense of sorrow and yet I took away an almost calm feeling. I type this with a somewhat mischievous grin on my face because that is another strange feeling that this film gave me.
This isn't just a film about a boy lost at sea.
It's a film about feelings and how we react to certain situations.
It is a film I will revisit many times over the years
It is...a difficult but successful movie that will make you ponder the meaning of many things.
Brilliant direction.
Score, FX, 3D...pretty much everything is absolute perfection.
Watch it just once with an open mind.
Some will love it, some will hate it, some will never understand it and most of us will take away something different from it than anyone else.
And that is the real magic of this film.
Very difficult but very rewarding.
Recommended.

Life of Pi(released Sept/12)stars,among others,Suraj Sharma as Pi,age 16,Irrfan Khan as Pi,adult,Tabu as Gita Patel,Pi's mother,Adil Hussain as Santosh Patel,Pi's father and Grard Depardieu as the Cook. This is a stunningly visual treat which keeps you mesmerized through a good part of the film. The animals that one sees through a good part of the film,are mostly CGI creations. And it is not hard to tell that they are just that,but the film doesn't linger too long on them as to undo your suspension of disbelief altogether. Lee just keeps pushing the story along.
And that story opens as a reporter in Montreal is interviewing an Indian man who starts to relate a rather bizarre tale;one that will have you "believing in God".The man relates as to how he got his name of Pi,as in the mathematical symbol. It seems an uncle liked a swimming area in Paris called the Piscine Molitor,and he became Pi for short. One day the father sees the writing on the wall and he decides to move his family to Canada;Winnipeg specifically. The father and the family run a zoo. They sell what animals they can and take the rest.
Part way through the voyage,just past Indonesia,a fierce storm comes up and the ship sinks,taking with it Pi's entire family. In a lifeboat hanging from the davit,there is the ships cook,into which is thrown Pi. Suddenly a Zebra loose from below decks,jumps from a storey up and onto the boat,breaking both its legs and sending the cook overboard and the boat into the water. Pi ends up in the water more than once but witnesses from under it the ships last breath as it sinks beneath the waves like a surreal lighted leviathan. Pi makes it back into the boat. Next morning things start to move. A hyena suddenly appears from under the boat awning cover and starts to harass Pi and the Zebra. Suddenly an orangutang joins this motley crew. It isn't long before the hyena gets its sea legs and it starts to attack and kills the zebra. Time passes and it goes after and kills the orangutang. Just as it is about to attack Pi a tiger comes out from under the awning and kills the hyena. From this moment on Pi must learn not only to survive but survive without getting eaten by the tiger.
For the first part of their journey Pi builds himself a makeshift raft on which to live,keeping a rope attached from the boat to his raft. Eventually,after many travails,and at the end of his rope,Pi comes on board and teaches the tiger how to behave when told. It surprisingly works and the two get on relatively well. They come upon a floating island whose inhabitants are mostly meerkats. It has fresh water ponds in which to drink and the tiger has plenty of food(meerkats).As Pi lay asleep in the night the meerkats take to the tress and the tiger goes back to the boat. The why becomes plainly clear when at night the ponds become acidic and kill everything that are in or may fall into them. Pi and the tiger leave the island the next day. They eventually wash up on shore in Mexico and are rescued.
Shortly thereafter reps from the Japanese shipping company come a calling to Pi asking questions about the reasons behind the sinking and his story of survival. Pi relates the tiger story to them and when they ask for the truth he relates another story of he being stranded with his mother,a sailor and the cook. The sailor was injured and the cook killed the sailor. When a struggle occurs later his mother pushes Pi to safety as she gets stabbed to death. Pi later returns and kills the cook and drifts alone at sea until he reaches Mexico. In the present the reporter looks at the actual shipping report and it seems the reps chose the tiger story over the other. When asked by a now grown up Pi which one he preferred,he replies the tiger story also. The film ends as Pi introduces the reporter to his two children and his wife.
After all we have seen and experienced Lee decides to give us a nice twist of an ending. Which story would we have preferred to see?.....the tiger story of course,and that is what we got. As the film begins one wonders where it is going as it visually describes Pi's childhood,which has its funny and serious moments. But the movie really starts to take off at about 30 minutes into the film when the ship begins to founder and sinks. One really feels like you are right there with Pi as he experiences the monumental loss of not only his family,but his way of life,all his belongings and the ship that would take him to a new life. With just his wits,some common sense,the teachings of his family and his religious beliefs,he must somehow survive and endure an indescribably tough,but at the same time,beautifully rich life trial. Along the way we are treated to a myriad of visually stunning moments such as the appearance of bio luminescent fish and a whale who breaches as it comes up to feed on same,the meerkats on the island,the sinking of the ship and so many more. And,if you haven't guessed,they are just that much more stunning because it may not have been real to begin with....right?
Technically speaking the film is in its w/s a/r of 1:85:1. There is an"extra"category on this DVD but all it contains are trailers. Kind of a false advert if you ask me.
All in all a treat for the visual senses. A simple story told with a straightforward touch but with a heck of a twist ending. The CGI animals are good but not fool proof,and Ang Lee steers his film with a deft touch never lingering too long on any one thing. It was nominated for 11 statues and won four. Well deserved. 4 1/2 stars. Excellent but not perfect.

The Short: A visual marvel. A human triumph. A test of faith. Finding God. An incredible story. Life of Pi is this and many other things, sweeping the viewer away into a mesmerizing place that blurs the lines between dream and what is real.

Ang Lee directs the previously thought un-filmable book to the big screen, Life of Pi. How it comes to life is breathtaking; an ingeniously woven tapestry of incredible visual elements and powerfully adept storytelling, all to the affect of discovering the greater meaning of being alive in a situation you would rather die in.

It's an art movie that many audiences will love simply because of the gorgeous visuals, memorable character(s), and incredible spectacle. But for those looking for a deeper, meaty, and memorable movie going experience Life of Pi has you covered. No other movie nominated for best picture at the 2013 Oscars has perplexed me, moved me, made me reflect and think, and swept me away within its lush, visual imagery and unique storytelling. It's a film chock full of metaphor, visual imagery, and raw emotion. But this isn't a discussion of the film's many layers of religious undertones and imagery, but a review. I'll keep it that way!

First off is director Ang Lee's incredible talent on display (for which he won Best Director - 2013). I have yet to read Life of Pi but from what I've heard from friends and book junkies is that Life of Pi is an incredibly complex, almost muddy in direction, novel which many considered un-filmable. What becomes of this epic tale of survival is a clean and expertly directed film, with all of its themes and underlying tones hidden within the visual landscape and story. It's not a force-fed experience, but rather one where you must process the vast array of information and make your own judgment on some of its less touched-on ideas. Whatever creative process Mr. Lee went through to bring this incredibly complex adventure to life is beyond me, and that's a true testament of the genius on display.

You can't talk about Life of Pi without discussing the incredible visuals. Winning both Best Cinematography (2013) and Best Special Effects (2013) at the 2013 Academy Awards, I had high expectations going into Life of Pi. The film starts off, simply put, like any other PG-rated family film. I was nervous that it was going to be a bust. Where the film takes the viewer is someplace completely unique and unexpected. Without spoiling some of the finer moments, Life of Pi has visual panache to spare. There are some incredible moments that are rendered and recreated with such life-like detail that getting lost in Pi's tale is tremendously easy. Its visuals dazzle, but don't distract its storytelling, unlike other films (namely Avatar, which is a visual marvel but hardly a groundbreaking example of storytelling). One of the main strengths in Life of Pi is Richard Parker, the Bengal tiger that accompanies Pi during his quest. Little did I know that that 90 percent of his screen-time is completely computer animated. And it's not just that, but the rest of the film; the water effects, the tumbling ship, various animals; all of it is incredible. It maintains a perfect balance of realism and a dream-like quality. Some of the scenes are also shot with incredible vision and beauty. It's simply the most beautiful cinematography of any film last year (other than the Hobbit). I have nothing but praise for Life of Pi's cinematographer and special effects team.

But no story is worth being told without great characters and actors to tell them. Life of Pi's Suraj Sharma (Pi) is absolutely fantastic. Emotional, powerful, and sincere; he is one seriously talented actor for never having been in a role before...ever. While the beginning of the film features a quick romance between Pi and Gita, featuring its fair share of awkward exchanges, its nothing annoying. Pi and his incredible story is what you see 90 percent of the time. It's his story of finding faith in the darkest of times, discovering courage where none should be present, and having the will to continue to live. The rest of the supporting cast does just fine in their various roles, aiding along the telling of a most grandiose adventure.

Everything else is spectacular as well. The original score (also winning the Oscar for Best Score - 2013) fits the pages of Pi's story like clockwork. From the moving "Pi's Lullaby" to the gorgeous and ethereal "First Night, First Day", the original score never distracts but rather augments the experience, creating some of the most beautiful audio-visual-scapes in any film from recent memory. Sound editing is particularly fantastic. Crashing waves, minute sound effects; it's all done particularly well, especially in its transition to home video (aside from a couple of weird boom adjustments made mid scene that distract the acute ear). And boy, I can only imagine the splendor of the 3D this film had to offer but I, regretfully, was not able to see it in theaters, only on Blu-Ray. The one issue I had with the visual presentation was this, also noticed by Blu-Ray.com: "There are two spots in the film where the aspect ratio changes suddenly from the normal 1.85:1. During the "flying fish" sequence that was used as a teaser for the movie, the top and bottom close in to 2.35:1, and there's a single overhead shot of a whale passing beneath the lifeboat that inexplicably squeezes in to a window-boxed 1.33:1. I'm not sure what the rationale or workflow was here, so I can't really comment on it, but don't be alarmed by the out-of-nowhere framing changes." In layman's terms, the film goes from a whole-screen experience to having the black bars on the top and bottom and sides during two scenes, which is fairly distracting.

Where Pi finishes his journey is up to you to discover and interpret. Where it stands for me, personally, is my favorite film of 2012. Visually spectacular, incredibly engaging, intricately told, and masterfully directed, Life of Pi was a massive gamble that pays off in more ways than one. It's an absolute classic.

Overall for me it was a pretty good movie. The plot had an interesting build up and kept you watching. Some parts dragged on, and for me were unnecessarily long and boring. And other parts left you thinking "What the heck?" I don't what to spoil anything for those who haven't bought it yet, but for those who did see it, what was up with the tooth??? This story had all the makings of something great... and it was expertly destroyed.

The entire aspect of this being a story told with religious intents should have been removed. The religious messages in the actual story told by Pi are perfectly fine, but the messages the movie itself tries to send with the building and falling action doomed the movie to mediocrity.

If you remove the first and last ten minutes or so of the movie, it would have been absolutely epic.

The visual effects, the emotional turmoil, the life-in-the-balance struggles, the twists, all were superb... if only it didn't begin and end with whispers and whimpers... You could remove the intro and ending add just a minute to the story and make this an epic tale of survival in the most incredible of circumstances, albeit with a rather fantastically mystical ambiance at times, but the attempts to weakly convey a religious message ruined the entire drama.

More telling, perhaps, is that it even failed on delivering on its own religious message. Not so much as causing one to think for a second as to its initial claims... except to wonder when the big moment was to come, only to be greeted with the closing credits.

I've got close ties to this movie, so I may be a bit partial. However, it is a movie that I can watch multiple times and find something new every time I watch it. While it isn't a scary movie, I wouldn't recommend it for children since it deals with more mature subject matters that young children cannot grasp or appreciate. The animals are not cutesy "Noah's Ark" fluffy cuddly animals. They are *real* animals with real animalistic tendencies. I would definitely recommend this movie for anyone wanting to get away from the usual movie plot.
great movie in fact i watched it twice so far. A must see flick...you felt you were living the experience with Pi....
Great family movie. Maybe not for very young kids. Will be watching again.  There are some beautiful scenes in this movie.

It was good but not as good as I had been told.

Director Ang Lee gives us a surrealistic vision of a young man sharing a small boat on the high seas with three animals, including a fierce Bengal tiger. There is never a dull moment in this beautifully realized blu-ray film, which is based on the book of the same name. Don't miss it.
My mom is actually the one that rented this movie - she liked it and said that she loved all the animals that were in the beginning of the movie -
Loved the story!  What a touching and beautiful insight into the way we look at ourselves and the world around us.
It was a different movie, seemed a bit slow but the concept kept your attention. I will say I did like it, but I don't think it was worth the price.

This movie excels in so many ways, but special mention should be given to the cinematography, direction and acting.  Visually, this is pure eye candy.

From the standpoint of direction, with one small exception, it is flawless.  That flaw is the scene in the family's cabin while the ship is in very heavy seas.  Pi is leaning over the side of his bunk, arm hanging down, but there is no suggestion of motion.  What I can't decide is if this was intentionally done to make the severity of the storm a form of shock and awe, or simply, an omission.

The acting, especially all the age variations of Pi, was spot on.  everyone performed well.

The CGI in this film was outstanding.  You would be hard pressed to tell that wasn't a real tiger.  The 3-D was good throughout, with no obvious attempts to get oohs and ahs.

The storyline, for reasons that become apparent has some inconsistencies, but that is as it should be.  A well told tale.

The story has all the elements that make one involved in all of the characters, the ups and downs of one's choices, and thankfully happiness in the end.
I, personally would have liked to have seen a richer sense of spiritual awakening in the adult as he told his story, so I found it as a weight that kept the tone of the movie down.
I would watch it again and would recommend it to others.

I have heard what a wonderful movie this is.  While this movie is the most stunning beauty I have ever seen and digital special effects awesome, it is slow and sometimes boring.  The first 45 minutes except for the visuals and digital special effects at the very beginning are quite dull.  Then there is a ship wreck.  I've seen many movies about that and this one is different because there are animals in Pi's very small boat.  He learns to tame the tiger and become close to the tiger and this saves him.  However, not much else happens for most of the movie, some high frightening waves and spray and then back to the boy and the tiger doing the same thing for an hour or so.  I won't put spoilers in here.  However there is a second story and it is confusing and hard to follow and at that point after two hours, I turned the movie off.  The movie should not contain a second story which I understand after reading what the heck happened on google is horrible for someone seeking spiritual life.

Kind of a trivial story.  Kept waiting for it to develop.  Boy learns to live with Tiger in boat?

Not much to watch here I'm afraid.

Jack Rickard

But once I was trapped on a 15hr flight to Australia a few weeks ago I decided to give it a try. I truly enjoyed this movie. I really felt like I wouldn't and guess I even went in trying not to. Its a good movie with lots of moments of life's reflection. Well worth seeing.

I've given myself a few months to digest this film, since I feel as though my initial response to it may have been jilted thanks to my unapologetic adoration of the novel.  Jilted in a bad way, since I felt this paled in comparison and so I was almost angry at the film for being critically successful.  Taking these few months to let it all marinade, I have to admit that not a whole lot has changed from my initial feelings.

While reading `Life of Pi', on a plane coming home from Europe, I was spellbound.  Page after page kept me intrigued and absorbed and engaged and completely in awe of everything being expressed and expounded on.  The journey and magical quality of it all was one thing, but the spiritual undertones and the way it beautifully developed the themes of faith and God were so articulate yet never condescending or overbearing that it all felt so effortless.  Up until that point, I had no real interest in the film adaptation that was fast approaching, but after putting the book down I was overcome with this intense desire to see Lee's film.  When I saw that it was a PG rated film, obviously directed at families, I was a bit hesitant.  It's not that the novel was extremely graphic, and yet in parts it really was and I just couldn't understand how you could try and make this a family film.

Still, I had to see it.

For those unfamiliar with the story, the basic premise is this.  A young boy named Pi (pronounced Pee) grows up in India on a zoo with his family.  At a young age he becomes fascinated with the idea of God and faith and religion and begins to study and practice multiple religions in an attempt to bring himself closer to God.  When his family decides to sell the zoo and move to Canada, Pi finds himself on a boat with a crew that dislikes him and a slew of animals in cages awaiting their destiny overseas.  During a terrible and unexpected storm everything goes awry, Pi's family is killed and he is left destitute on a life boat with a hyena, zebra, orangutan and Richard Parker, a Bengal tiger.  For 227 days, Pi has to learn to survive alongside this beast.

It is an intriguing tale and one that it mostly approached from an angle of respect, and I must admit that the way Lee visually crafts the film is marvelous, but outside of those visuals I found the film to be almost shallow in its presentation of the more intimate and important themes of the story.  The core of the story is lost in a film that becomes redundant and superficial.  I think a big problem with the `translation' of the film is that the key segments on the book are all internalized.  You read the thought patterns of young Pi and you begin to become entranced in his world.  In film it isn't always easy to convey internalized transformations and so the outward redundancies (yelling at the tiger, starving, fishing, yelling at the tiger) carry less weight.  While there is tragedy at the center of the film, it became almost too focused on the visuals and so it lost the heaviness needed to carry the emotional side of the story.  It became pretty, but empty.  I also found the changes to the story to be unnecessary.  Pi's love interest was a ridiculous inclusion, especially since there is no development of that story and so their separation carries no weight.  I also found the whale scene to be kind of pointless, yet pretty, and while I understand the idea of creating tension thanks to the aftermath of the scene it just didn't do what it set out to do.

The way the film is spliced is also somewhat irritating, although I'm sure it was developed to try and add some interruption to the redundancy of Pi's struggle.  The constant shifting from present to past and the use of Irrfan Khan (elder Pi) as a narrator for many of Pi's actions felt forced and took me out of the story, to be honest.  It also took some of the key moments in the book (like the adventure on Meerkat Island) and condensed them to the point where they were almost pointless.  I understand the need of narration to explain certain things that visuals won't readily explain, but these segments were so short that they almost trivialized their inclusion.

I'll admit, the conclusion is still heartbreaking, and when the big question is asked, "Which story do you prefer?", I can't help but feel the lump in my throat.  I also can't help  but reply, "I prefer the story Yann Martel told me!".

Still, `Life of Pi' is a beautiful film.  The visual effects are some of the best I've ever seen in a film, and for that it richly deserved its Oscar.  I take issue with the cinematography Oscar, since the skies and sea were all created by the visual effects department, but whatever.  This was purely a director's film in the end, and so for that I guess Lee's Oscar shouldn't be all that shocking to me, although I really don't think he deserved it.  He may have created a visually arresting film, but the core of this film was not a visual one but an emotional and spiritual one and he failed to tie those ends together (for me).

Despite the heaviness of the actual prose, there is something `slight' about this interpretation.
One of us had read the book before viewing, the other had not, but both of us enjoyed this film. It is such a beautiful film, and one that leaves you reflecting.

While I had not read the book, I am now inspired to do so, and hope that I will be equally impressed by the writing as I was with the movie.

The acting of Infan Khan was wonderful, and he truly embodies his character and allows you to see not only the joy that he has in his life but also the pain, guilt and sadness that has come with it too.

The movie was beautifully done and you get to see and experience a movie that I believe will definitely last the test of time as one of the great ones!

As is obvious from the number of rave reviews this film LIFE OF PI was are sounding success in the theaters when it was shown in 3D. There is no question but that the story, so well known over the past decades since the publication of the book of the same name by Yann Martel, draws everybody in, whether because of the indomitable spirit of our surviving hero or the religious aspects of the story.  Perhaps because of all the hoopla about director Ang Lee's manipulation of CGI effects and the endless interviews about the making of the film that make the final product (on DVD at least) seem so contrived and unreal that some viewers will find the end product less than satisfying a version of the novel. David Magee sculpted the screenplay from the novel and while that provides a lot of background about the character of Pi before the main event of the lost at see episode, it does seem disruptive at times and in this viewer's response robs the story form some of the poetry.

The story has been summarized elsewhere as follows: `In Canada, a writer visits the Indian storyteller Pi Patel and asks him to tell a story. Pi tells the story of his life since he was a kid in Pondicherry, India and the origin of his nickname. One day, his father who owns a zoo tells his family that his business is not good and he had decided to move to Canada and sell part of the animals in the United States. They travel in a Japanese cargo ship with the animals and out of the blue, there is a storm followed by a shipwrecking. Pi survives in a lifeboat with a zebra, a orangutan, a hyena and a male Bengal tiger called Richard Parker. They are adrift in the Pacific Ocean and when the tiger is hungry, he eats the other animals. Soon Pi learns that he might find a way to feed and domesticate the tiger to survive.

The character of Pi Patel is played for the most part by Suraj Sharma while his earlier years embodiments are shared by Ayush Tandon and Gautam Belur and the adult storyteller by Irrfan Khan. Pi's parents are played by Adil Hussain  and Gita Patel and his brother Ravi by, depending on age, Ayan Khan, Mohd Abbas Khaleeli, and Vibish Sivakumar,  Rafe Spall is the writer who will create the book from Pi's story, and for a few brief moments Grard Depardieu plays a Cook on the ship.

There are some very beautiful scenes of skies and waterscapes, but we are left wondering how much of this is carton created in the large studio tank that serves as the ocean. Some of Martell's original explanation of the various religions Pi adheres to are retained: they were the best part of the novel. Perhaps in 3D this film would have worked better. Grady Harp, March 13

...fable I would say.  I looked forward to seeing this film after all the hype (to say nothing of the Academy Awards), so it was inevitable, I suppose, that I was disappointed.

The tension between the rational and the ineffable -- science and religion, reason vs. faith, has always been my favorite literary device.  Think "Inherit The Wind", Spencer Tracy version.  The only new insight here is the line "Someone else introduces us to God when we are young" (I paraphrase).  I let that sink in.  True enough.

This movie reminded me in some ways of "Cast Away" -- ship/plane-wrecked at sea and lost on a deserted island.  One man has a Bengal tiger, the other a Wilson soccer ball.  Of the two films, "Cast Away" works more cogently for me at illuminating the human condition.  Faith or Fact?  The fork in the road -- the crossroad at the end of "Cast Away", and all the choices which preceeded it.  I'm not being dragged into a discussion of whether or not I "believe in God", or "which story I believe".  Better the mirror held up to see the reflection of a lifetime of choices.

The atheist and the person of faith share the same conundrum: neither can speak rationally about the unknowable or metaphysical.  And since no one really knows, we all must wait until our fate meets us.  And therein liveth the fable.

ADDENDUM:  I watched this movie a second time in order that I might better connect with the dialogue and narration.  I understand the question (is there a God?), but not the conclusion here: God is in the story.  Life is full of sorrow (polio, shipwrecks, evil people -- which includes the hero here, as he admits in his second version of the story), but also of beauty and joy.  But what we experience as "real" depends on how we tell the story?  And that's where we find God?  Too thin for me.  I do appreciate the author and director for tackling this question, however.  That alone makes this a better-than-average film.

ADDENDUM #2:  I bought the 3D BluRay, and I must disagree with the people who say the 3D effects are lacking.  This is the best 3D movie I have purchased yet, including "Avatar", "Hugo", "Bolt", and "John Carter".  The 3D effects are very good on my Sony 3D BD player and 65" Vizio 3D HDTV.  The hummingbird at the opening credits popped right out into the middle of my living room, and I actually got seasick while watching the sinking of the ship.  Really amazing.

I was assigned to read Yann Martel's LIFE OF PI in a college freshman lit class over Thanksgiving break.  I had the misfortune to fall sick that Monday, and was bedridden until Friday.  Martel's novel kept me company; in between bouts of passing out, I'd read about the epic journey of young Pi--a journey both physical and spiritual.  I loved the novel; after six years of college literary courses, it remains the only book I've been assigned that I subsequently went out and purchased, and reread, before the course was over.

I never expected, or wanted, to see a film version.  Like many great books, PI is rooted in its literary origins.  And as such, the film version does suffer slightly--what comes off as exciting and insightful in the novel can seem somewhat boring and lackluster (at least, plot-wise) onscreen.  This is only to be expected.  And yet, David Magee's script sticks faithfully with the novel, right down to much of the dialogue.  In the form of our tortured hero--I use the word lightly; "protagonist" would be a better term--we have Suraj Sharma, giving a solid performance (the fantastic Irrfan Khan plays the older Pi, with Rafe Spall playing the Writer).  The problem with the film, aside from the slow pace (which isn't nearly so slow in book form) is that Sharma is out-acted by everything around him; that's only to be expected when you have a film that looks so absolutely beautiful.  WIth vibrant colors, rich textures, and just an overal REALNESS to the cinematography, PI blew me away (and I only watched the 2D version).

But the true star here is Richard Parker, Pi's carnivorous raft-mate.  Perhaps the pinnacle of modern CGI (an actual tiger was used for some shots, but mostly it's the computers), Richard Parker comes truly to life under Ang Lee and company's masterful hands.  The fact that a fake tiger is the focal point of LIFE OF PI isn't an accident; it's a beautiful film with a dangerous edge, easily mistaken as a life-affirming, optimistic piece.  Truthfully, the film follows the novel's spirit as well as plot: you take from it what you bring to it.  Maybe its ambiguity in such matters can be counted against it; if the movie (and novel) had taken a true stand, there might be more to admire.  Still, LIFE OF PI--whichever form you approach it in, though I highly recommend the novel, even if Martel's other works fall short--is a story to make you think.  Maybe you'll walk away happy, maybe you'll walk away depressed, maybe you'll just be frustrated and confused; the point is, you'll walk away feeling SOMETHING.  And if that's not the point of art, then I'm not sure what is.
